<Rating>1	1	1	3	3	3	1	-1	

<Author>FlyboyPA151
<Content>Other than some word games - no surprises After comparing multiple Theatre District hotels on Tripadvisor, I chose the Belvedere based on the overwhelming good reviews and the price point. I usually use Kayak.com to set a price benchmark, but interestingly enough, the Hotel's own website undercut that price by a good $20/night at $169/night for a one night stay in a King Deluxe room on January 26th.When I called to make the reservation, I asked for a recently remodeled room and the receptionist was very coy about giving me one, saying that they assign rooms at Check in. After a little pressuring by saying that I would just make my reservation elsewhere where they could guarantee a specific room, she said she blocked off a refurbished room for me. A very good - but deceptive - choice of words, as I would find out later.The morning of our departure, I realized that in making my reservation, the receptionist nor I had ever discussed a rate. I had a bad feeling in the pit of my stomach which was substantiated with a call to the hotel to confirm the rate of $169 (plus tax) a night. As it turned out, they had my reservation down as $199/night and I had to talk to a manager to get them to honor their own online rate (he didn't even know about it until he went and checked the website himself). In adddition, I asked the manager about having a renovated room and he said that was $75 MORE a night and went on to say that I had a refurbished room, which apparently means only a few things have been upgraded, including the mattress, linens, etc. Be careful when you book and make sure you are aware of the use of these words by the hotel!Because the rate was still a good one for the area, I kept my reservation and upon arrival, the check in experience was nothing like the experience over the phone. The door was opened by the bellhops and my fiance and I were greeted warmly by everyone in the stylish, clean lobby. There were no surprises at check in and our room was ready within minutes of our arrival.As a side note, the hotel is located in the theater district, but a bit off the beaten path. It's a bit seedy, but it could be much, much worse.As a previous reviewer noted, the elevators were slow, but since were were on the 16th floor, we really didn't mind the wait. The hallway on the 16th floor (as well as any other un-renovated floor) was small, a bit dated, but clean and neutral odor. The room was not as dated as I expected and was very clean. The marble entryway and bathroom was spotless and very inviting. The linens were clean and soft and the view from the 16th floor (room 1603) was actually very nice. One noticeable absence however, was the lack of in-room climate control for heat (there is a window A/C unit for the summer months). Regardless the room was comfortably warm and we regulated the temperature by using the A/C unit's thermostat to keep it at a constant 67-68 degrees.I was a bit disappointed to find that Wi-Fi costs $10 for 24 hours, and they even charge for use of the business center, but I will note that there were at least 4-5 other unsecured wireless signals that my laptop was able to receive - even from the 16th floor.Overall, the experience at the Belveder Hotel was unremarkable, but it did meet expectations for the price paid. You will not be surprised - either negatively or positively, but you will not regret staying here either. Although they have not given me a reason to not try other hotels, they do get a solid recommendation as a reliable, clean stand-by if all else fails. Just make sure you confirm your specific reservation, room type (renovated vs. refurbished) and rate prior to arrival and all will be well.On a side note, Pigalle, the french bistro located a block away is an excellent restaurant. I highly recommend the escargot there - very tasty and done just like I had them in Paris!  
<Date>Jan 28, 2008
<Rating>3	3	4	3	4	4	2	2	

<Author>FamilyManTraveller
<Content>Excellent hotel value in Midtown We stayed at this hotel for one week in early July 2007. We were able to get a good deal for the hotel room from Expedia. We were very pleased with the location and services at this hotel. This high-rise hotel was refurbished a few years ago from its original apartment residence and there are still a few longterm apartment tenants but you would never know it. Our room accomodated two adults and two teenagers without it feeling too cramped for a Manhattan hotel. The washroom and beds were clean and fresh daily. The lobby, surroundings and indoor environment were well maintained, bright and inviting. It has a central location (two blocks from Times Square, near a couple of subway entrances) that allows easy access to all that Manhattan has to offer. Surrounding restaurants within walking distance were plentiful and reasonably priced. The staff were all friendly, pleasant and accomodating. Definitely a real hotel jewel for families in Midtown and we will be back here the next time we visit New York City.

<Author>AmishLou
<Content>Rooms very nice, BUT... We stayed in a King room on the third floor. It was a recently remodeled room and we were very pleased with the look of the room and the size of it. By New York City standards, it is HUGE! The bed was comfortable with nice linens. However, I would probably not stay there again for several reasons. The worst thing is when you step off the elevator onto your floor you feel like you're in a college dorm. The hallways are narrow and didn't have a fresh smell to them at all. The elevators are very slow and very small -- each time we waited for one on our floor to go to the lobby and the elevator would open, it would be packed with people. Since we were on the third floor we ended up using the steps to get to our room. The worst thing was the noise. The road noise was awful but I realize it's NYC and it's always noisy. The problem is the windows are not very airtight so you could hear everything from the traffic to the kids coming  going to their school across the street. We thought to turn the fan on for some white noise but found that there is no climate control in the room. The people in the room next to us were watching TV till 3 in the morning and we could hear it all. The maids were out in the hallway talking by 9 AM, which woke us up. The bathroom is very nice but could be larger -- there is no place to put toiletries. A shelf would have been very nice. There is a small refrigerator  microwave which is nice, but I would have preferred a much larger bathroom instead. My husband  I had to take turns getting ready. The breakfast buffet was pretty lousy -- nothing special to it at all. After the first day we decided we'd much rather eat breakfast at a NYC deli. So there are pros  cons -- the price was good ($189), the room was very clean and nice, but the noise bothered us enough that we will look for a different place to stay next time we're in the city.

<Author>11NYC_Traveler
<Content>Inept for business travelers The Belvedere, which is a clean, relatively modern hotel, should be avoided by business travelers or those needing internet access. First, while they advertise wireless access they only provide it at $9,95 per day. ok. However, it is an unreliable system as each day I have twice not been able to relog on and each time the hotel want to connect me, to technical service in some voice mail jail of a third party provider. After waitng far too long I have demanded a second username and password; which for 2 days they just gave me. Today they refused. They they put someone on the phone who claimed to be the manager . Imagine a manager dealing with a guest's log on issues. This place is definitely mis-managed. So, I finally said I refused to waste my time on their problem, and await technical support as my computer works all over NYC wirelessly and has here also. So, I am finally just accessing the net via my phone and avoiding their poor service. In addition, its only 802.11b and for $9.,95 a day you would expect at least g service. Finally, I will simply share the the sheets are cheap the bed spreads look like my grandmother's and the chair did not fit in front of the desk so the desk was useless. Other than that, so far, and I'm 4 days into a 6 day trip, its been ok. I think I will check out a day early and just never return. I come to NYC every 4 weeks and have found plenty of other more enjoyable places such as Casablanca, Hotel 373, Club Quarters or the Residence Inn all of which accomadated my needs just fine. I just like to try new places which is why I ended up here, but not again.

<Author>fins823
<Content>Fine, just fine We had a pretty uneventful stay. Staff was very nice and accomodating. We were originally in a room on the 8th floor and found it wasn't high enough (in terms of street noise) and they easily moved us to a room on the 14th floor. If you're a light sleeper, I would definitely recommend the highest floors. We had no problems dropping off and the valet parking. Room was a decent size by NY standards and a good location for midtown. The decor could stand a little updating, and especially the hallways which looked a little worn and dreary, but wasn't a big deal. Try the French place right up the street for breakfast.A previous poster mentioned a trip to Woodbury Commons, but it is in New York, not New Jersey - about an hour northwest of the city. A definite must if you have the time.All in all, a positive experience. It's amazing the price of the room and the accommodations (we found a deal at $250-$350 a night), but that's New York for you - nothing is cheap!  
<Date>Jan 13, 2008

<Author>Maggiepie
<Content>Don't tell our secret The Belevedere is a great little hotel. It was a very last minute trip and we were hoping for a good price. We booked thru Jet Blue website and could only get a double bed room. When we arrived and breezed thru check-in our lovely Desklady asked if that was what we wanted. I asked for a kingsized bed room and was given a very nice corner room with a king on the 14th floor. Small kitchenette with sink, fridge and microwave. Comfortable, clean, quiet with a very friendly staff. Great location. Close to Times Square and all the theatres and restuarant row. Try the Delta Grill on the corner of 48th and 9th. Elevators were fine, just a little warm. Remodeling of 17th floor was no bother. Would most certainly come back again.

<Author>NYLisaNY
<Content>Not so great I do not think this hotel deserves the rave reviews that it has received. The rooms are small and mediocre and the service is substandard. First and foremost, the road the hotel was on was closed. This may not seem like a big deal, but in the TImes Square area, it can literally take 45 minutes to go around the block. Therefore, not knowing the road was closed added more than 45 minutes to our trip. In addition, there was no way to drop people or luggage off in front of the hotel. What is most upsetting about this is that the hotel admittedly did nothing to notify its guests when it knew of the road closing at least 24 hours in advance (ie emails or posting notification on its website). We never saw a door man or porter in the hotel. When we upset our frustrations, the management simply stated they we sorry we felt that way.If you are looking for a relatively inexpensive hotel this is okay, but there are much better places at similar rates in NYC  
<Date>Jan 6, 2008
<Rating>2	3	2	3	3	2	1	2	

<Author>LABUNNY
<Content>Great Location for Trade Show  I stay at this hotel whenever I have a trade show in NYC. It's about $5-7 cab fare to the Javits Center. It is close enough to the convention center, and at the same it is near Hell's Kitchen/Times Square. They are a lot of great restaurants around this area, so if you feel tired, you don't need to walk too far to find some great affordable restaurants. There is also a supermarket nearby called Food Emporium. The hotel service is not the best, but it is OK if you don't expect too much service. The rooms are clean and roomy enough for NYC standards. What I like about this hotel is that it has a small kitchenette (microwave, sink, fridge, and a coffee maker).

<Author>minskyuk

<Author>xj355ic486x
<Content>Perfect!!! I visited the Big Apple with my Mother and sister Dec 11-18 and stayed at the Belvedere 49th st. As soon as the cab pulled up we was treated like royalty. The looby is very clean and the staff were very friendly. We stayed on the 14th floor and had a really good view of the city. The rooms very quite spacious, only one little bother was the fact that there wasnt enough sockets to plug electrical things in. This wasnt really a big problem we just had to take it in turns to charge phones etc. The inroom entertainment is very good. There is a choice of pay per view movies which include many films that are still in the cinema. It works out at 拢6/$12 per movie.I'd read some reviews about the lifts being quite a problem. I didnt find it to be a big problem. I think the longest we waited for was 3mins.There is a cafe within the hotel which offers a breakfast buffet for $18/拢9 if you like your food and will eat most of the buffet then it would probably be worth the money, but if you only wanted tea and toast forget it you still had to pay the buffet price. (It probably seems like Im writing a negative report Im really not just trying to give a well rounded account of the hotel.A very good place to get breakfastt is the Olympic diner on 8th avenue. You turn left out of the hotel and when you reach the bottom of the street turn left by the flower shop and about 6 shops up you'll see diner. It was 拢3 for 3 huge pancakes, Tetley tea which was very hard to find in NYC, juice and water. They were very nice people in there too!Times Square is literally a 5 minute walk from the hotel. Turn left out of the hotel and keep going on straight. You have to cross the road by the flower shop but keep going straght and you will see a Hershey shop, look right and you will see all the Neon lights. I heard reception telling someone a 10-15 min walk. Its is honestly a 5min walk if that!Macys is down to the flower shop, cross the road to the right by the Brazilian grill and keep walking straight down to 34th st then cross the road and walk 2 blocks and you're there. Probably a 20min walk and there is plenty of Bargains to be had. Take sone ID i.e passport or drivers Licence to prove you do not live in NYC and you will get a discount card for 11%. You have to go to the info desk which is up some steps by the watches.For bargain hunters Woodbury Common in New Jersey is a must. You can purchase a ticket to go from the grey line tour operators who wear red coats and are on every corner especially Times Sq. Its $40 and an hours ride away. You can get Timberland boots for $40/拢20!!! I paid 拢90/$180 in the UK. Footlocker is very good too. You will be asked to sign up for a loyalty card, just say yes it does not go through bank it just gives you money off. I had vouchers for $25 off $100.Applebees is a really good place to eat, its alot cheaper in Woodbury Commons because they dont have city tax but its still reasonable in NYC. Duane Reade which is only practically every corner is a good place to get snacks and drinks to take back to the hotel. With the rooms having a kitchenette you can store plenty of things. The fridge is very big too.I would definately stay at the Belvedere again! The staff/room was fantastic. The whole Hotel was spotless. You could not beat the location! The Rockefeller Centre is a 10-15 min walk away. The empire state just by Macys. The best way to get around is to buy a Gray Line hop on hop off bus ticket. A 48 hour pass is $50/拢25 and worth every penny. They stop at Times Sq, Macys, Ground Zero, Statue of Liberty, Wildoff Astoria, Central Park amongst lots of other stops!I hope this review has helped! If there is any questions please contact me! I will be happy to praise this hotel more. I would go back in a heartbeat!  
<Date>Dec 23, 2007

<Author>suzstav
<Content>Good location We stayed at The Belvedere for a quick weekend Christmas visit to the city. It's Westside location was good for getting in from Newark Airport, but it you're coming in from La Guardia or JFK you may want an Eastside hotel. But it was close to the theater district without being in the middle of it, and within an easy walk of Rock Center, Radio City Music Hall and all the holiday stuff we wanted to do. Hell's Kitchen and the far west side (9th Ave, even 10th to a degree) are much better now than when I lived there 15 years ago -- great restaurants and fairly safe -- so The Belvedere was a good choice for price, cleanliness, location. The staff were very accommodating. The rooms weren't large, and the views stink, but who spends time looking out a hotel window in NYC??

<Author>Lafemme1975
<Content>Excellent value, location, need I say more? I'm just back from a 4 night stay (3rd -7th Dec) in The Belvedere hotel in Midtown Manhatten. 3 of us travelled over from Dublin; myself and my 2 sisters (25 and 16) for a few days of sightseeing and shopping. Having seen the hotel on the hotelconnect website I tried to book it with them but unfortunately they had no availability so I managed to get a booking on the hotels web-site. I can't rate this hotel highly enough; we had a double double i.e a room with 2 double beds and having read reviews of the hotel I was concerned the room might not be big enough for 3 avid shoppers but there was plenty of room for us, our belongings and all the extra belongings we picked up along the way. The hotel is literally 5 min walk from Times Square and about 10 min walk from 5th Avenue. We walked everywhere.....as everything was so accessible! There are loads of places to eat on the same street as the hotel although we didn't try any of them. The hotel also has a restaurant although we didn't eat there either; I would however recomment La Pigalle which is on the corner downa bit from the hotel and Maxies is the next block down. La Pigalle was very handy for breakfast as it's a 2 min walk on your way to all the sites anyway. Id read reviews about slow check-in and waiting on lifts and from our experince we didn't encounter such problems....in fact check-in is from 4pm but prior to leaving Ireland I emailed the hotel to see if it would be possible to have our room ready on arrival as we expected to arrive at about half 2 or 3pm ....having heard nothing I figured we mght not be so lucky but low and behold our room was ready and waiting for us. We were checked-in and in our rooms within 5 mins, staff on reception were extremely friendly, professional and helpful. We had a room on the 5th floor...we did find the room a little cold as a draught blew in around the air-conditioning unit but it was easily fixed by placing some shoes against the curtains to hold back the draught and it didn't warrent complaining to management about. One of the evenings we returned to our room to find a chinese take-out menu under our door......a little strange considering the restaurant is downstairs but on our last evening we were so shopped out that we couldn't manage leaving the comfort of our room so we ordered in and there were no complaints! Top tips for a first-timers trip to the Big Apple: 1: take the open top bus on your first day as you'll get your bearings much quicker and get a real feel for the city, try and see the city from Top of the Rock and the Empire State, we never got to the ESB unfortunately, 2: if you like shopping you have to go to the Woodbury Common Outlet....its $39 pp by bus form the Port Authority. We got our tickets through the hotel concierge but get there about a half an hour befre th us leaves as there might be a bit of a queue. The journey is about an hours drive upstate but so worth it! We shopped til we dropped.....literally!!! 3: A cheaper alternative to the Liberty/Ellis Island ferry is the Staten Island ferry...we missed the last ferry but hopped on the SI communter ferry and the views were just as good. If going this time of the year try to get the 4pm ferry....as the sunset is amazing on the way out and you get to see the city lighting up as you come back. (Hope to include some of our photos later) 4: The Rockefeller Centre is amazing and will really get you in the mood for Christmas! Shopping wise; Woodbury Common is worth it, give Century 21 a miss unless you're a fan of TK Max and like to rummage!! I was a bit disappointed with Macys, maybe it was just too big and busy but I was looking for a winter coat and didn't see anything I'd wear but maybe that's just me. We never made it to Bloomies....but there's always next time. And you can't go to New York without visiting Tiffany's......and you'll be surprised at what you can actually afford! And not forgetting Ambercrombie and Fitch...well worth a visit if only for a photo of the half-naked male model in the door-way!!!! All in all we had a great time and had no problems while we were there, in fact we're already planning our return visit to the Belvedere.  
<Date>Dec 10, 2007
<Rating>5	5	5	5	5	5	5	-1	

<Author>Dr. Pub
<Content>Believe the Reviews....The Belvedere is a Great Stay My wife and I just returned from a 4 night stay at the Belvedere. The hotel exceeded my expectations.ROOM: The rooms are small but not tiny. Our first night we stayed in a standard room. For the next three nights we moved to the 15th floor, which has been renovated and appears to be an executive level floor. The room was much nicer than the standard room and had marble floors, better spacing, and nicer furniture. Specifically, we were in a corner room (#1501) which is slightly larger and has two windows. You actually have a good view of the Hudson River from this room. I paid $75 per night extra to be in the upgraded room and would do it again in a heartbeat. I will request this room when I return. Check out the NY1 internet rate on the hotel website; this includes a full breakfast buffet for occupants each morning.LOCATION: On West 48th Street between 8th and 9th Avenues. I liked this location better than the mononlithic 5th Avenue hotel we stayed in last time. This feels more like a neighborhood. Within one block: Duane Read (a grocery/pharmacy chain store), Pigalle (a great casual French brasserie with great beer selections, and many other restaurants. The Theater District's Restaurant Row is only two blocks away on 46th Street and we walked to all of the plays we attended. Lots of restaurants and shops around. Other than the occasional ubiquitous emergency vehicle siren, noise was not a factor.FOOD: We ate breakfast in the Belvedere Room several mornings and found it to be pretty good with a lot of selections.SERVICE: The hotel has doormen and bellmen; also a concierge. We found all of the staff to be very friendly. There is a gift shop with newspapers, soft drinks, toiletries, and souvenirs. I thought the elevators ran just fine and I never had to wait over a minute or two. The lobby is well appointed with Art Deco furnishings.VALUE: With holiday rates averaging over $500 per night in many hotels, I found the Belvedere's rates to be fairly economical by New York standards. Only if I got an unusually low rate at a name upscale hotel (W, Renaissance, Westin, etc.) would I stray from the Belvedere.My only complaint: the Business Center has four computers for internet access, all of them for hire at 0.25 per minute. They actually have bill acceptors and credit card swipers for each one. After sinking my $5 bill for 20 minutes of e-mail reading, I was disappointed to find the service s---l---o---w. It took me over four minutes to open the first e-mail. Lockups were frequent.In summary--Trust the high ratings the other Trip Advisor reviewers give the Belvedere.  
<Date>Dec 7, 2007

<Author>ExcitedToTravel_68
<Content>The Belvedere - Service at it's best Staying at The Belvedere was a great experience. The hotel itself was beautiful. The rooms were spacious and confortable. The service was more than we expected. I loved everything about staying there. On the same block there was a corner florist. The flowers were gorgeous and really set the mood everytime we walked past it back to the hotel. The best feature was the pricing. Because it was a few blocks from the hub of Manhattan, we were able to pay a lower rate than had we stayed right near Times Square. However, it was so close, it was just a few minutes walk to that area. And being in NY, walking was half the fun. I have recommended this hotel to many friends and family. I look forward to another visit.

<Author>Ireland77Ireland
<Content>Loved the Belvedere Stayed at the Belvedere for 5 nights in November, 6 ladies (between the ages of 29 and 48) and 2 rooms, we had ample space for 3 in each room and it never felt too crowded even with all the suitcases and daily purchases we made!! The hotel was clean, warm and comfortable and the staff were all very nice and helpful. We were up early every morning and gone for the full day between sightseeing and shopping we did not have time to sit around the hotel and find fault with so much to see and do in he city!!! We thoroughly enjoyed our experience in the hotel and would defo go back there again. It is in a perfect location, a block from times square and within walking distance of Macy, 5th Avenue, Rockefellar centre and central park. We walked absolutely everywere but what better way to get the feel of the city!! I would recommend La Pigelle on the corner for breakfast and Hurleys restaurant one block up from the hotel for steaks!!! We also felt extremely safe around the hotel and the city in general. The hotel was just perfect to come back to after a full day of walking, sightseeing and shopping. The room was cleaned everyday and fresh towels placed in the bathroom. We also did the hop on hop off tour which we found to be a great help and got us to places we may not have seen otherwise!! It is worth $50 for the 48 hour useage. The TOTR was absolutely brilliant and the views were amazing!! I would also recommed using the staten island ferry for a view of the Statue of Liberty, its free and it gives an excellent view. Woodbury Common was also worth the trip out!!! We just loved everything about the city and the hotel was the perfect base for us to come back to!!!It may have been our first visit to NYC and the Belvedere but it certainly will not be the last!!!

<Author>DestinyFarm
<Content>Wonderful jewel We stayed at The Belvedere for three nights on our first trip to NYC and found the hotel much, much better than expected. The location in Mid-Town was excellent as a base for getting to all the major sights we planned to visit. Our executive double bed room was very clean withcomfortable beds and the amentities exactly what we required. Without exception, the hotel staff was friendly and helpful. They offered great restaurant suggestions on Restaurant Row (within 2 short blocks). The Bellman were the best, especially Louis and David. They stored our luggage upon check-out for several hours until our flight and arranged a clean, safe car and driver for our departure trip. I had read reviews about the slow elevators and we did not find that to be a problem. However, we did plan our arrivals and departures around the busy checkout hours. What I really appreciated, was the quiet location on 48th Street. After all the noise of getting around the city, it was very quiet and restful back at the hotel. We enjoyed our stay so much, that we extended our stay by an extra night. We will definitely stay there again. An excellent value hotel for NYC.

<Author>WestCumbrianLass
<Content>Belvedere is great! I've just read the other reviews here and I have to say this. I have stayed at the Belvedere 3 times, for 7 nights each time. On every occasion I have never had a complaint to make about the hotel. The first 2 times there was myself and my mother on an extended shopping trip. Hotel is conveniently located 5 mins walk from Times Square and about 20 mins walk from Macys. It is easy to get back to to deposit your shopping and get back out to do the sights without wasting a lot of time. The 3rd time I was there with my family (parents, husband and 6 month old son). I asked for a crib on arrival and one was delivered within the hour to our room. Rooms were spacious enough with 2 double beds in each, plus floor space for all your shopping - definitely take an empty suitcase!! Bathrooms adequately sized for 2 people in a room.We never ate in the hotel as there is a great diner just round the corner, and the deli on the corner is 24 hours. Food Emporium 2 mins walk up the ave will provide you with a smorgasbord of culinary delights.The subway is just a block away (A/C line) and you can of course transfer to any other line from Times Square station.Yes, there is a fire station at the corner of the street, yes the taxis honk all night, yes the bin men come every morning but hey, it's New York. It wouldn't be right if there was no noise!!I cannot fault this hotel - I wouldn't have gone back if I had a problem. It has always been reasonably priced, within walking distance of most major attractions (Statue of Liberty is a subway ride away). Check-in desk staff are friendly, the doormen are wonderful, friendly and polite (especially when staggering back in the early hours!) Never used the concierge for advice as have been many times before. Internet access available down in the lobbby (take dollar bills). The lifts are slow so if you're on a low floor and are able to, just walk up/down the stairs. Alternatively, nip down the corridor and use the service lift!Seriously, I think this hotel is great and have recommended it to several friends. I'm about to book a week in NY for next Easter and the Belvedere is at the top of my list. I can't wait!!Please feel free to ask me any questions about our stay(s) and trips, I will gladly answer them.  
<Date>Nov 23, 2007

<Author>raveman2001
<Content>For the price I got can't do better in NYC I got lucky and paid $170 canadian. I see that $250 or more is possible for this hotel, so book wisely. For the price I paid it was a great deal for the location. Doorman and valet were ready on arrival. Couldn't check in at 11am but took my bags and asked if I wanted a call when the room would be ready. Got back to the hotel at 4pm and room was ready. I was pleasantly surprised, for New York was a good sized room with a king bed, nice simple furniture. Bathroom was nice, had some marble and there was a sink, microwave and fridge in a small kitchen style space. Decent size closet as well with a safe. Plently of TV channels and very helpful staff. Bellmen always prompt. I noticed the heating is controlled centrally which is odd, and one time we felt the room getting cold but the heat came on.It is a block and a bit away from Times Square, and while is 3 star, is prob as good of a 3 star as possible. Try to get a deal, you'll do better than a lot of other budget hotels in NYC that are 2 star.

<Author>ZacmanMontreal
<Content>Never ever again ...big time disappointment!!!!!! Where to begin....I booked through the manhattan club website...I requested a deluxe room with 2 queen beds...and received confirmation...upon arrival, I was very surprised that my room was far from deluxe and had only 2 double beds...I promptly went to the front desk to enquire and was told that there were no rooms with 2 queen beds. I then asked if I could upgrade my room, I wasn't asking for a freebie, I made it crystal clear that I was willing to pay any price to switch rooms...I was told that there were no rooms of superior quality....so...my 4 night stay became a 1 night stay....I spent the next 3 nights at the Parker Meridien...much more expensive, but at least you get what you pay for...This experience has left me wondering, where exactly is the room that they show on the manhattan club website, it actually looks quite nice, but not at all like the one I was given...so buyer beware, if you want an economical room, this may meet your standards, however, do not expect much or you will be bitterly disappointed....

<Author>kels0
<Content>Good for those on a budget! I have just returned from a stay at the Belvedere, NYC and value for money wise am quite pleased. Let me start off with the good: it was under 拢500 for the 3 nights. It's pretty central, a 3-5 minute walk to Times Square, would be better if it was 1 block to the east but whatever, walking is the best form of seeing New York anyway. Service was good, Chris the concierge was very helpful with attraction ticket and general NYC advice. Room was spacious, bathroom was nice.The bad: there is no room service, the breakfast was $17.50 and bit of a rip-off, the room we stayed in was forward facing onto part of 48th street and im not even sure it was double glazed as you could hear every little noise. Bearing in mind the yellow cabs honk at each other well into the night, and the bin men come every morning prompty at 5am making a racket to wake anyone. Overall though value for money it is just what you expect, a reasonable hotel though there are definately better places to stay in New York, if you're on a budget however, the Belvedere is for you.

<Author>analissa
<Content>no hesitation in recommending the Belvedere Thanks to the previous recommendations of this excellent website we have just returned from a very enjoyable stay at the Belvedere. We were warmly welcomed by the reception staff and delighted with our large double double room on the 12th floor. The hotel was spotless and as we had booked directly with the hotel an excellent breakfast was included in the price. The hotel is located on a relatively quiet street within five mins walk of Times Square and close to the subway which we mastered with no problems at all and we felt safe at all times. I visited the following attractions etc based on information trailed from the New York forum section and would like to recommend the following ; The New York Party Shuffle bus tour.Use of [--] for discount printouts for theatre tickets.Hurleys restaurant .(go out front door turn left ,cross to the Pigalle walk straight on and it is on the RHS.) Very reasonable and excellent food.Top of the Rock for fab view of the city.Jersey gardens shopping outlet.A walk in central park and a snack in the Boat House restaurant.Restaurant row in west 46th street 8th avenue.... two minute walk away.Maceys... a lovely store with good choice of food downstairs.Carmel private cars for return journey to the airport.

<Author>UTAHRULES
<Content>WOULD GO BACK IN A HEART BEAT Location was great, couple of blocks from time square, food and shopping. The concierge was out standing and really helped plan our time with many suggestions. Rooms are not large but it is well laid out. They have a mini kitchen area and a little grocery stores around the corner to stock up. I suggest taking the tour bus approx. $35 per person. It takes you all over the hot spots. And you can get off the bus and take as much time as needed to sight see (bus runs every 20 min) Take extra cash as eating is not cheap. We kept things to munch on in our little kitchen area and ate one good meal out.

<Author>keetseel
<Content>two thumbs up! booked reservation directly with hotel and received NY1 rate which come with full breakfast for 2, (kids pay half of full price which is around $9) breakfast was exceptional. Staff very courtious and helpful. Hotel location is quiet . Walked everywhere without any hassles. For Broadway shows - highly suggest using TKTS booth loacated at Marriot Marquis on 46st and Braodway for best ticket prices. (most shows avail, except very popular ones eg..Jersey Boys, Wicked.. Given great seats without asking!! Note - Hotel concierge quoted much higher price for Phatom tickets than what I actually paid for them at TKTS booth (booth opens at 3pm and line does build, but moves along quickly). Can't recommend any restaurants around the hotel that I ate at (both Italian food)---they sucked! poor service, over priced and food lacked taste and quality. Wished I would have tried the mexican food place next door though - the food there looked good. Recommend hot dogs from the street carts. Wanted to eat at HOP KEE in chinatown ( recommended by a local), but never made it . As for the room - you get what you pay for. It was comfortable, small bathroom, blah blah blah...I didn't come to NY to sit in a hotel room all day. 2 adults/2 kids slept great regardless of air conditioner noise. Maids kept room very clean, have no complaints. Use service elevators at end of hall. Workout room had it all - no pool thought. WiFi wasn't free and signal only good, couldn't find an outside connection. Final words - Just book the hotel and be done.

<Author>Scovo
<Content>Okay hotel but definitely has some quirks! This hotel is okay for the price. It was one of the most reasonably priced hotels I could find in Manhattan but it definitely has some quirks. When we checked in they only had one king-bedded rooms left so the couple we were traveling with settled for 2 doubles. Their room was on the 5th floor and the hallway smelled horrible. Luckily they didn't notice the smell in their room. When they got to their door the swipe keys wouldn't work so they had to go back to the front desk to get them reset. Instead of apologizing, they said Well they should have worked! The second day they asked to be moved to a king room so they were moved to the 17th floor. Again their keys didn't work. We were on the 16th floor - our room was nice enough but had an odd layout. There was a long hallway upon entering the room. The bathroom was tiny - the toilet was literally 2 inches from the wall. That was great advice that someone gave about using the service elevators at the end of the hall - they were so much faster. I noticed that when the elevator stopped on the 15th floor, it looked like that floor had been recently remodeled. It had dark wood doors and more updated carpet but I didn't get to see a room. We heard that there might be a taxi strike the day we left so we asked the concierge to book a limo to take us to the airport. It was half an hour late! We were so nervous about making our flight but i guess that wasn't the hotel's fault. One evening the bellman recommended a nearby restaurant - Tremonti's and it was the best pizza I've ever had! Overall our hotel experience wasn't bad but wasn't really great either. My two favorite things we did on this trip to NY were the new observation deck on top of Rockefellar Center (we bought tickets at about 5:30 so we'd be at the top for sunset - it was incredible and much nicer than the top of the Empire State Bldg) and the other thing was sitting at the outdoor bar at The Boathouse in Central Park (it was a gorgeous day and we had a blast there).

<Rating>4	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	

<Author>Babygaybe
<Content>Great location. Very good value for money in New York. My partner and I spent 7 days in total at this hotel this month, (Oct 2007), and were very pleased with value and service.Location is excellent; central but no noise disturbance at night.We stayed 5 nights in an executive room; ( this was an upgrade we were given free on arrival). The room was very spacious-6ft bed and loads of space around it. The room also has a fridge, a microwave and a coffee maker.Clean and newly decorated; it was a really comfortable and welcoming place to stay.Staff all very pleasant and helpful.We had breakfast one morning and there was plenty of choice from the buffet. However, unless you book a bed and breakfast deal there's no point in being pinned down to the hotel for breakfast as there is such a vaste choice in the streets all around the hotel.There is no night bar to sit and chill out in but there is a fantastic little restaurant/bar just a few yards away, (the Mont Blanc); we ate there a few times and we used to stop off for last drink(s) on the way home. There is a lovely walled garden at the back which has a intimate and relaxed ambience. The owner and staff at this restaurant are really friendly and the food and wine were good too!Round the corner, (to the left), on 8th Ave, there's a coffee shop/supermarket with internet access which is open 24hrs. Two coffees for about a pound!Round the corner to, the right, on 8th Ave is an information shop where you can buy tickets for all the tours. Big savings when buying multiple sights. Don't bother doing the 3 hour boat trip. It feels like it goes on forever!About 100 yds past this tour shop is an Indian restaurant called Indian Fusion. The restaurant has been open about 2 months and is beautifully laid out. The food is fantastic! You take your own wine/beer so that's a great saving. Loads of eating places nearby and a short walk to all shows.Some sites give the Belvedere 3 stars, others 4. I'd say 31/2! After staying the 5 nights we went to visit family in Philadelphia and returned to the Belvedere for the last 2 nights of our holiday. On this occasion we were given the standard room we had booked and this was less roomy-though I'm told by a friend who has done New York a few times that it was a reasonable size by New York standards. There was still a 6ft bed but less space around it. The bathroom was very small. There was still a fridge, coffee maker and microwave.The only complaint was that the air conditioning was very noisy for the first 5 nights and I really struggled to ignore it. On the 2 night stay the air conditioning was reasonably quiet.We'll be going back to the U.S.A. next autumn and hope to spend a few more nights in New York. We will definitely use this hotel again. Review submitted by middle-aged, (lesbian), woman  
<Date>Oct 19, 2007

<Author>Hennerspenners
<Content>Great Location, Comfortable Hotel The Belvedere Hotel is situated on a side street off 8th Ave. It is 10 mins walk to Time Sq and 20mins to Central Pk. The staff were very helpful and polite. I requested a quiet room before we arrived and that is exactly what I got (apart from the air con but you will be so tired after all the walking you won't notice it). I shared with 2 friends and the room was a good size for a city centre location. It also had a fridge, microwave and coffee machine. We flew into Newark airport and caught the train to New York to Penn Station, this was a good 1/2 hr walk with cases so we caught a cab back to the airport which cost $70 but was much better. I would recommend this hotel.

<Author>stweaver
<Content>Pleasantly surprised I booked this hotel on Hotwire, which was my first time and kind of scary. However, after paying 269 per night for the hotel, and finding out about it on TripAdvisor, I was pleasantly surprised. The previous reviews about the hotel were fairly accurate. Some complained about the elevator being slow, but we were on the 6th floor, and found that we did not wait long. The room was a good size, the bathroom a little small, but for 2 people, very adequate. It was warm when we visited, so the air conditioner was used, it worked fine. The front desk staff was very helpful and accommodating. Concierge gave us some good tips. The bed was comfortable, the room was clean. The window opened a few inches. Room is very quiet with window closed. Our room faced 48th Street, which is not as noisy as it seems it would be. Hotel very close to Times Square area, a five minute walk, Rockefeller Plaza, most theaters, and several lines of the subway. We were very happy with the hotel and the room. Did not hear any construction going on, although we had been warned there was some construction in the hotel. Would stay here again for the same price. Door man and others in lobby very helpful. Hotel loaned us an umbrella on the one day it rained. Good restaurant Olympic Restaurant around corner for breakfast, inexpensive and fast. Leaving on Saturday, door man found us a town car to airport, $65 all-incl. to airport, taxi is at least $40 plus tip and tolls. Town Car much more comfortable, pleasant. Small complaint, hi-speed wireless isnt exactly hi-speed, and it is $10 per 24-hour period. Instead, ask for the 15-minute complimentary pass to use computer in business center if all you need to do is print your boarding passes!

<Author>prhuk
<Content>Loved the place - a really good place to stay! What a great little hotel! Coming from a previous stay at the horrid New Yorker Plaza it was such a relief to find this was so much better for a similar price and still very central (a short walk to Times Square). Whilst it is not especially impressive on the outside (in terms of 'wow - look at this') and had a fairly small but nicely presented lobby, the room we were given on the 17th floor was just fantastic. Good sized (but not large), bright, very clean, colourful, well decorated, very comfortable and a lovely bathroom. It also had a large fridge, microwave and ice bucket in a small kitchenette area which was very handy, and a safe in the room (free) plus a flat screen TV with a dvd player. Gym was small but good too, and you could also do your own laundry there in the basement which was really useful. A great find and highly recommended to anyone. Only one minor downside - too few lifts so waiting for them was often lengthy.

<Author>mackyUK
<Content>painfully slow and dysfunctional lifts I stayed at the Belvedere in January 2005 and give it five stars because of its great location and it also offered a fine service for two people.I have decided to review it again because I revisited the hotel in September 2007 over Labor Day weekend and with three people in the traveling party.Despite booking for three people, the rooms only had 2 queen beds with two adults sharing one of them. The cups, towels, coffee, chairs were all for two people despite paying for three and giving staff constant reminders that there were actually three of us stopping in the room.I can forgive the hotel for a poor service because it was very busy and staff were under pressure to cater for the large holiday crowed but what I cannot forgive is the hotels failure to spend some of their time and profit replacing and/or upgrading the lifts.As other reviewers have written, there are 3 small lifts that cover hundreds of rooms over 17 stories which at times can results in waiting for up to 10 minutes. My second stay at the Belvedere was ruined because one of the three lifts was out of order for the entire duration of my stay (5 days). Wait times for the remaining two lifts were over 15 minutes. Five hours of my five-day stay in New York were spent waiting for the Belvedere's painfully slow and dysfunctional lifts.

<Author>BATMANAZ
<Content>The Belvedere; My worst hotel experience ever! As both a business and leisure traveler who has put on almost 250,000 miles over the past 28 months, the stay at this place ranks as my worst hotel experience ever!After room rates, taxes, hotel ding charges for my daughter to also stay with us, I paid almost $400 per night for a room that would make a Hotel 6 look like the Ritz.The facility looks amazing from the exterior and first floor interior (ie. lobby), but that is where they must have run out of money. We stayed in room 404 on the fourth floor and the room was tiny. Sure, there was a kitchenette but you couldn't use the fridge which was on the floor, under the counter unless you got on your hands and knees because the door was hinged on the wrong side and the the entire space was probably no larger than 4'x6'. The bathroom was small, so small that if you tried, you could touch all four walls from the john.Need wireless internet? No problem, unless you expect it to work.Can it get any worse? Oh yeah. Step into the hallway at any time and you're floored by a foul oder. What did the hotel staff have to say about that? Well apparently this hotel has tenants from a period before it became a hotel and they can't do anything about them.At checkout, the staff didn't even bother to ask how our stay was, so other than leaving a comment card, they're clueless to my overall dissatisfaction but then again, I don't thing they would have cared...Stay somewhere, anywhere else; At $400/night, you'll be happier that you did...

<Author>jchurch
<Content>A Wonderful Hotel I've stayed at The Belvedere several times, usually for 3 or 4 nights at a time. I've thoroughly enjoyed every stay. The rooms are comfortable, staff is friendly, professional and helpful, and you can't beat the location. The little kitchenette is a big plus when you're staying for a few nights and want to skip the restaurant scene.The hotel is being rennovated, floor by floor and, on my last visit, I was given a room on the brand newly-done 15th floor. I was the first guest to occupy 1501 and, I must say, the re-do is impressive. The bath-tub is deep enough for a good long soak, much needed after walking the aisles at the Javits Center day after day, and the bed and linens are simply delicious. As with any re-do, there were a few glitches, but nothing not-fixable: the new wide-screen T.V. was very tempermental, there's a need for a full lenght mirror in addition to the one in the bathroom, and lighting for make-up is... well, I used the window.All in all The Belvedere is a wonderful place to stay.  
<Date>Sep 6, 2007
<Rating>5	5	5	4	5	4	5	3	

<Author>GeoffinUK
<Content>Positive experience overall We have just spent a week at the Belvedere. Overall, our experience was positive. The room was well sized, clean and comfortable. The staff were helpful, particularly the bellmen (when primed with tips!). We avoided the breakfasts, which seemed on the pricy side. However,we had a few niggles. On arrival, we were told that our rooms had not been prepaid, even though we knew they had been. Eventually, the mixup was traced to the hotel accounts office, but only after a rather panic-stricken call to our travel agent in the UK (at our own expense). Not a good start. Secondly, the elevators were slow and crowded, as others have noted. Thirdly, although the rooms were provided with a fridge, microwave and coffee-maker, there was no cutlery or crockery, apart from coffee mugs. They were provided on request, but why not just put them in place ready (as the Bedford on E 40th does)?However, a great location, and overall I would recommend this hotel.  
<Date>Sep 5, 2007

<Author>EvenMatt
<Content>Excellent hotel and location! We have just returned from a fantastic trip to New York and thoroughly enjoyed our stay at the Belvedere. We booked the hotel after reading other reviews on this site and it was even better than we had hoped. The reception and door staff were all really friendly and helpful and the hotel was clean, well decorated and air conditioned throughout. We were able to check in a little early which was well appreciated after a long flight. Our room was on the 16th Floor and we had a great view of the city which was particularly impressive at night. The room was a great size and the kingsize bed was huge and very comfortable. The kitchenette area was an added bonus and the fridge came in particularly handy for keeping drinks cool. The hotel has a number of pcs available with internet access at a reasonable cost which we used for checking in for our return flight. The location is excellent, really central and just a short walk to Times Square. There are loads of great places to eat nearby and we would particularly recommend La Masseria, an excellent Italian which was a 2 minute walk away at 235 West 48th Street. We had an amazing holiday and hope to return to New York again soon and we will definately stay at The Belvedere.

<Author>BI-Travelers
<Content>Great Experience at the Belvedere A referral from a friend as well as positive Trip Advisor reviews led us to book the Belvedere, and we're so glad we did. The location was ideal, the staff was most helpful, and the rooms were very nice and very reasonable as far as New York hotels are concerned. It is true that the elevators were a bit slow, but once we discovered the service elevator, we used it and were able to get to and from our room fairly quickly. One tip I would like to pass along is that I found the prices in the hotel gift shop were some of the most reasonable around. Also, don't miss Vynl, the restaurant located on 9th Avenue, just a short walk from the Belvedere. The food was great and very reasonably priced, the atmosphere was wonderful, and it is an absolute must that you check out the bathrooms--check ALL of them out--I did and was quite impressed. This was our family of four's first trip to the Big Apple and we will be back and when we return we will definitely stay at the Belvedere again. I highly recommend it to anyone traveling to New York.

<Author>markyhero
<Content>A Little hidden gem This place is hidden well ,you are only two streets from the hectic Times Sq but you would never know this as it peaceful place.The rooms are a good size with a seperate kitchen sink and good size fridge and microwave.There is a safe ,handy,.In the basement is a laundry room a nice clean place with great tumble dryers so pack even less make room for some of that great shopping .Check in was quick and so was check out .We stayed for 7 nights didnt use the gift shop or have breakfast here to busy for that.The doormen are very helpful all you have to do is ask ,we left our cases with them on the last day and they arranged a cab to the airport we had no hassles at all.It was a pleasure to let someone else do the arranging.We took the hop on hop off tour which is well worth the money and had the New York pass as well ,plenty of attractions to see with that including a 2 hour night cruise which is lovely.I am for going back to the Belvedere if I ever return to New York as it lived up to all its reviews and I wouldnt want to chance some of the others .Also I think it was a fair price for what you got.We (husband and two kids12.14.)had a third floor room and didnt have any problem with noise outside or in.

<Author>dolphinbabe73
<Content>Overall best experience I have had in a hotel!!! This was my first trip to New York and I did a lot of research before booking my stay at The Belvedere and I was 100% impressed with my entire experience. The staff went above and beyond to assist us and were extremely friendly from the front desk to the bellman and doorman and even the maintenance guy. We stayed in a room with 2 beds on the 9th floor and it was not a huge room, but it was a really nice sized room (especially from what I hear that most NY rooms are very small) I never heard any of our neighbors the entire 6 days we were there, which means the walls must be pretty thick. The microwave and fridge are very convenient too. Beds were pretty comfortable and cleaned promptly every morning. I read a lot of people complaining about the small bathrooms and yeah, they are giant bathrooms, but honestly how long do you plan to spend in the bathroom on vacation anyway? The water pressure was great and we always had plenty of hot water. I also hear a lot of people complain about the slow elevators but we never experienced a problem the entire time we were there. I also read the post before mine and they mentioned the elevators down the hall from the main ones, and we used those a few times and it was always right there so I am not sure what the issue is. This hotel is in the BEST location, you can walk just about everywhere and its right near the subway station as well. I really do not have any complaints about this hotel. If you book with The Belvedere, you will not be disappointed.

<Author>GrandCayman
<Content>Don't stay anywhere else! My husband and I just returned home from a 4-night stay at The Belvedere in NYC's Broadway/Theatre District. I had searched for months for the perfect hotel for us because my husband is very specific on what he likes (if it were up to him we'd be at the Four Seasons or Hilton!), and all of the reviews I read online about The Belvedere were good so I took a chance on this one. I was thrilled to find the rooms discounted on Travelocity for a Summer Special so we ended up paying about $200 per night for a double room. Not cheap, I know, but everything else was much higher and the Milford Plaza - although more affordable - was not going to be good enough for him. I had stayed there with my best friend last year and although great for us it is always crowded and the elevators are so slow we ended up taking the stairs down 18 flights of stairs each day. I am so glad I chose The Belvedere instead!The hotel has everything you need to make your stay a comfortable one, and the location is perfect. When we arrived by taxi from LGA airport - about a 35 minute drive - we were greeted at the door by a bellman who quickly took care of our luggage. Check in was swift and the concierge answered our questions about shows, directions etc. with professional and knowledge.We were pleasantly surprised to see that our room had a mini fridge and sink which we filled up during our stay with water and some fresh fruit from Chinatown/Little Italy. It also had a mini safe which we stored our passports and valuables in, an iron and board, spacious closet, drawers, full length mirror, TV, ice cold AC and more. The bathroom was European in style and spacious by NYC's standards. We were very comfortable and had everything we needed.We will definitely stay here again. And the best part for me? My husband didn't complain once about the room or hotel!

<Author>Utilitypro
<Content>Great Value Hotel We have stayed here twice in the past couple years and love the hotel. Its location is great...between 8th and 9th avenues on 48th street. It has a great corner grocery a 100 yards from the hotel and with a mini fridge, microwave, and coffee maker it was handy for purchasing various knick knacks to eat on. Staff is great...some mention slow elevators but if you will look to the end of the lobby or the end of your hall you will find a faster elevator that many are not aware of. Do not stay on the top floor...rooms are smaller than 14th floor. This is not a luxury hotel but is a very clean, convenient, safe place. Taxi ride from LaGuardia is $32 plus whatever your tip is.

<Author>Nic9
<Content>Superb location! Great hotel! It was my husband and I's first time in New York City and I did a lot of research before booking us into the Belvedere Hotel. My research paid off big time!!This place is in the best location if you are wanting to base yourself in the Times Square District which I would definately recommend if you are a first time visitor to this huge city. A word of warning I would avoid the hotels right in Times Square because gee its noisy! We could hear the noise from Times Square in our hotel room all throughout the night so I cant imagine how loud it is directly in the square! But after the first 2 nights we got used to it. But if you dont, there are always earplugs! The hotel website states that its 5 blocks from Times Square but its only 1.5blocks, it takes less than 5 mins to walk right into the centre of Times Square.The concierge were extremely helpful, couldnt have been nicer when we needed them, but stayed in the background if we didnt need them. The room was small, but my husband and I stayed for 9 nights and had 60kgs of luggage between us and didnt find it a problem. The place is not luxurius but its definately very comfortable and clean. I really think you'd be hard pressed to get better value or location. If you want a hotel restaurant this isnt the place for you as it only does breakfast I think but who wants to dine in a hotel when youre in New York!!Definately recommend it for the average traveller who cant afford Trump Towers or the like, but who doesnt want to stay in a dive either. I give it a big thumbs up!

<Author>LSC06
<Content>Great Location; Helpful staff I recently stayed at The Belvdere in New York City for three nights. I was part of a group of 29 all staying at the hotel. The location was fantastic. They were both tourist traps with terrible food. Ask the staff at the Belvedere for recommendations - they never sent us to a bad place. We look forward to returning to the Belvedere.

<Author>Deb-Phil
<Content>One Word - Excellent Just become a member so thought I'd share past experiences with other travellers.Went to NYC for my 40th birthday in June 06, booked fairly last-minute, looked at hotels on the net and found the Belverdere, can only say this was ideal, room  hotel spotless, staff v. friendly, always willing to help, check-in was a breeze as was check-out, room cost $1100 for 4 nights in King Deluxe Room, it had a small kitchen area, bathroom, loads of storage, tv/playstation/internet access - ideally situated to see the city, would stay here everytime due to its location, staff, cost ................ well everything.Stumbled upon BB Kings jazz club (237w 42nd St, 7-8 ave) about 1hr after dumping cases in room, and was back there later to watch James Brown in concert for my birthday (ticket cost $86), what a treat and an excellent club with its own small jazz bar next door where you can have a drink and listen to some cool jazz sounds after the concert. BB's also do sunday brunches with live gospel which we didn't try but believe they are excellent value.If you're looking for a limo service for airport pick-up use NYC limos (Lance) and liberty helicopters offer excellent service on heli tours, we booked limo on line and used hotel to book heli tour, and I have used the same companies for my MD's family holiday since coming back and always been given an excellent service.We didn't get to do everything we wanted as things were happening in NYC that were advertised on the TV in hotel room (Puerto Rican Day parade, Big Apple BBQ event), so make sure before you go if anything special is on, you make enough time.ALL IN ALL, AN EXCELLENT HOLIDAY IN NYC, JUST NEED TO GO BACK TO FINISH MY SHOPPING and do more sightseeing/trips.

<Author>reayx5
<Content>Exceeded my expectations! First trip to NY. Checked out a lot of hotels online. Saw good reviews for this place. Saw bad reviews. Took a chance and booked at the Belvedere. Our experience was wonderful. My story is below. If you just want the quick review - You can not beat this location - Super-clean hotel - Lobby: bright and airy - Our room: unbelieveably clean, quiet, and comfortable (no smelly rooms or halls) - All staff:excellent. OK, here's our story - The front staff was great, especially Director of Front Office - Steve Vargas. We arrived quite early in the morning after a red-eye flight across the US. We were exhausted, but our room wouldn't be ready until normal check-in time.We left all our bags securely with one of the doormen (Eric - who wasalways with a great attitude - always recognized us - always helpful). We came back in the early afternoon, just hoping the room would be empty. Not yet. Steve could see how tired we were. He was going to let us stay in another room until ours was ready. My wife just happened to mention that it was our 25th anniversary. Steve did a little talking to the woman working the counter (another helpful employee whose name I wished I remembered). He suggested an upgrade to another room, gave us a free night, and the small additional cost to us for the better room was well worth it. I cannot emphasize how clean the room was, every day of our stay. The bathroom was spotless.I do the cleaning in our house, and I know a really clean bathroom. The staff was unbelieveably good. The bed was just right. The climatecontrol was just right. Our view, overlooking the front street (from the 9th floor) was of skyscrapers above, and a Performing Arts schoolacross the street. Not a noisy street, and within a one minute walk of a city that is on the go! Got five minutes? Walk to Times Square, Broadway shows, great food. No more than five minutes tops! I suggesteating at Junior's for breakfast, lunch, or dinner. You want it, theyhave it. Fast and cheap, with great service. A good play; Curtains - minutes away (buy your tickets cheap at TKTS in Times Square). Again,I can't say enough about the staff of The Belvedere. We will return to New York, and we will stay at The Belvedere!

<Author>melissacarley
<Content>Location location The Belvedere's location is perfect! Only minutes from Times Sqaure and two streets away from the infamous restaurant row on 46th.The hotel was clean and the room was fairly sizeable considering we had been told that hotel rooms in New York tend to be on the small side.Unfotunately we did have an unpleasant experience though. On arrival (after 20 hours of travelling) we were told that our room had been given away to someone else, regardless of the fact that we had booked 6 months in advance and had called to confirm the reservation just the week before. So instead of two double beds we got one double bed and a pull out camp bed on the first night. But still paid the same price! We got the room we had booked for the remainder of our stay, although it was a tad annoying as we had to change rooms after the first night and I was faced with having to sleep on a camp bed after all those hours of travelling!The staff were pleasant although did not take responsibility for mistakes they had made e.g. assuming we were all checking out when one of our party left earlier than the rest, so disabled our key cards then accused us of demagnetising them.All in all it was a good hotel, which is very basic although comfortable and close to everything. I would recommend this hotel for people who are spending most of their time out and about and just need somewhere clean and safe to come back to at night.Some of the roms have been refurbished, which have more comfortable beds and more modern bathrooms. Ideally you would want one of these rooms, although the older rooms are still ok.

<Author>HouCut
<Content>Belvedere met expectations We stayed at the Belvedere for 3 nights from May 29th - Jun 01. Thanks to Trip Advisor we had a good idea of what to expect when arriving at the hotel, but our expectations were exceeded. The staff was terrific from the moment we arrived to the hotel in the taxi. We arrived at the hotel at about 7:00 pm, and the room was ready when we checked in and we were in our room within 5 minutes. The bellhop brought our luggage to the room shortly thereafter. The bellhop, Luis, gave us tips on where to eat, locations of convenience stores, and where to catch the subway. The hotel is in an excellent location on 48th street between 8th and 9th Ave. Its a quiet street, and only a few blocks from the theater district and Times Square. We were able to walk to Times Square and to the Broadway theater to watch the Color Purple. The Grayline bus tour is located around the corner on 9th avenue for the hop-on hop-off tour of Manhattan. There were some previous reviews that voiced concerns on the elevators being slow at times. During our stay that wasn't much of an issue, I never waited more than 5 minutes for an elevator. The housekeeping staff also did a good job in cleaning the rooms. We typically didn鈥檛 leave until 10:00 am, and the room was always cleaned when we arrived back, either after lunch or later in the afternoon. The concierge desk was very helpful as well, providing information on which subways to catch to go to certain destinations, and booking tours for us. We didn鈥檛 eat in the Hotel, but if you book directly thru the hotel, the breakfast buffet is included in the price, which is a $16 value.

<Author>swampy511
<Content>Great hotel in central location After the fruitless search of numerous hotels reviews on this site - we decided to book this hotel following positive reports from other travellers.We wanted to be within walking distance of Time Square and the central Manhatten attractions and this hotel was perfectly located. Despite being just two blocks from Time Square, the theatres and other main attractions, the hotel was in a quiet street with no traffic noise. (On a previous trip to NYC I had stayed in Hotel Pennsylvania... and didn't want to make the same mistake again!!)The staff were welcoming and friendly and the room was perfect with an extremely comfortable bed and wet-room style bathroom. The room was spacious and furnished in a very modern style and the bathroom had a marble washstand which was a lovely feature.Although priced more expensive than ideal - the hotel offered great value for money when you consider that this is central Manhatten!!Breakfast was not included - but I heartily recommend 'Pigalle' a french cafe/restaurant on the next block. <Author>JasonBuberel
<Content>Great location, good value My wife and I spent 5 nights/4 days here as part of our 10 year wedding anniversary excursion to New York City. The Belvedere was recommended to us by a coworker who had lived in Manhattan and he did not steer us wrong. The hotel was easy walking distance from all of Broadway, Central Park, Times Square, as well as all of the important subway lines. At the same time it is not fully in the middle of things which gives it a more secluded feel. The room was small but clean and well appointed. We were not bothered by the noise of a nearby elevator or any of our neighbors. The wireless internet access worked very well, but they do charge a daily fee for it (about $10/day). We did not make use of room service or laundry service, nor did we eat at the hotel restaurant or bar. I did make use of their fitness facility, which was about as good as can be expected for a hotel. They have modern (as of 2007) Life Fitness equipment - two treadmills, a stair climber, two elliptical trainers, and several exercise bikes. They have one multi-station resistance unit which was in good repair. It is no replacement for a full gym, but it will do in a pinch.We paid for our stay partly with United Mileage Plus miles, so cost was not a big factor. That being said, their published rates are decent.

<Author>kt_mc
<Content>Lived up to the excellent reviews!!! I stayed at the Belvedere hotel with my mom on a 5 day trip to NY in March 07. I booked the flights at christmas as a present for my mom as she has never been to NY. I then spent a few months looking at loads of difffernet hotels as there are just so many!!! We agreed that we would go for a 3 star and after looking on trip advisor the one that kept jumping out with great reviews was the Beledere. I booked it and was surprised at how reasonable the price was compared to others. The location was also just so perfect as we knew we would be going to shows. When we arrived we were not dissapointed,it is so central and the doorman was just so lovely. There was no wait at reception and one of the girls in particular there was so friendly and helpful when asked the silly first timers questions that she must hear day in day out!!! The lift was a little on the slow side but it didn't matter to us as we were only on the 4th floor so could take the stairs. I was pleasently surpised with the room. NY hotel rooms are usually very small but this one fit two double beds with plenty of room around them. Room was kept spotless each day and everything functioned the way it should do. Yes the bathroom was slightly small but how much moving around does one plan to do on the toilet!!! There is a kitchenette which came in very handy for the use of the fridge. There is a little gift shop with everything you could need and internet and phon access. The only little things were that we were at the front and the street outside can be a bit noisy in the morning but sure where in NY would you find peace and quiet and why would you want it in such an amazing city!! Room could get quite warm but we didn't turn on AC so im sure it would have cooled down if we did. At the end of the day, how much time does someone visiting NY spend in their hotel room and if they do then why did they bother going to a city that has so much to do and see!! I will return to the Belvedere next time im in New York as why spent so much time trying to find another suitable hotel when you already know of one!!

<Author>Gavcol
<Content>Very pleased Very pleased with this hotel. Stayed 3 nights. Booked online through hotel site without any recommendation, and not sure what to expect so we were pleasantly surprised. Clean and well appointed rooms. Furniture and flooring looked new. Beds comfortable. Staff were very friendly and helpful. Corner store nearby for fruit and snacks if desired. Noted on the fire chart on room door that the 4 rooms directly across from the lobby elevators appeared to be larger and deeper than the other rooms (we had one of these rooms on the 12th floor).

We were on the 6th floor and maybe lucky with quiet neighbors, but we didn't hear a peep from anyone next to us or above us. <Author>SueEdinburgh
<Content>A good base for our trip to New York I visited New York last week with 2 girlfriends for a 3-night stay and thought the Belvedere was a good choice. The location is very central, just 5 minutes from Times Square. We shared a room on the 6th floor at the back of the hotel and it was comfortable and quiet. We had to request extra towels but they arrived within 5 minutes of our request. The staff were friendly and helpful and we thought the hotel was good value for money. We did not try the hotel breakfast but instead had breakfast in the Olympic Diner round the corner on 8th Avenue which offered plenty of choice and an authentic New York experience with a real mix of people eating there - locals, workers and tourists. I would be happy to use this hotel again. If you don't do anything else when you are in NY, visit the Top of the Rock for the most amazing uninterrupted 360 degree views of the city.

<Author>Ohiofiremn
<Content>Great Location for Times Square and Broadway Stayed here for 2 nights with the NY1 plan ($269/night - King deluxe w/ full breakfast incl.) - Bellhops were prompt and very helpful - front desk was prompt and courteous - we had booked the room using the hotel website - no problems at check in - we were given room 1706 - top floor - which provided a great view of the city - the room was small but not cramped - small bathroom and small area with sink/micro/fridge - all of this was fine as we were only planning on sleeping in the room. The room was very clean and the bed fine. It was exaclty as expected. Room would probably be better suited to a queen bed if you feel tight but I understand all rooms in NYC are pretty small. We did not have any issues with the elevators and never waited for more than a few minutes one - and we were told the hotel was full the second night (Saturday). The breakfast was great and fresh. I would not want to eat the same thing for more than a few days but for 2 days it was perfect. Both days we had perfect weather and walked to dinner and our broadway shows.We drove to the city and parked at the garage the hotel used. It is on the next block ($27/night) and had no problems with the people there.Simply put , we had a great stay without any issues whatsoever and would recommend this hotel - if we stayed somewhere else it would only be to try something different.

<Author>onebadhatharry1
<Content>Great Hotel and Location This was our first trip to New York City and therefore were slightly taken aback by the wealth of hotels on offer. After much research we settled on The Belvedere Hotel and what a great choice we made. Firstly the location is perfect just two blocks from Times Square, in just five minutes you are in the heart of New York. Also being in Hells Kitchen you are in the middle of many wonderful restaurants and bars. Checking in was easy and we had our keycard after two minutes. Our baggage was taken upstairs by the extremely helpful porter. We were on the top floor (17th) and the room was spacious and extremely clean. It had it's own fridge and kitchen area, Sky Television and a queen size bed. The bathroom was also spotless and modern and the maids came every day. The only downside were the two small lifts that service a hotel of that size and it can get cramped between 8am and 9am in the morning when everyone is leaving the hotel. But this is a minor gripe, it is a great hotel and well worth the stay.

<Author>KateP1
<Content>Great location and price We visited New York for four nights in March 07. I was really struggling to find a hotel in our price range which had good reviews on this site. Then I came across the Belvedere and I'm so glad I did!The hotel is in an excellent location; just a couple of minutes walk from Broadway and about a ten minute walk from Times Square. There was a subway station just around the corner.We found the staff to be very friendly and helpful. The hotel was clean and the room a reasonable size (I have been told that they are large rooms for New York city). There was a small kitchenette with a fridge, sink and coffee maker which was good. The room was very clean and had two large double beds.There is a Brazilian steakhouse attached to the hotel and we were planning to eat there on our last night but unfortunately we couldn't as we didn't make a reservation early enough as it was so busy. There were also good restaurants near the hotel in all price ranges.We loved New York and if we go back there again, we would stay at the Belvedere.

<Author>amiecat85
<Content>Great Location! My boyfriend and I stayed at the Belvedere Hotel March 28-30th, and had a very good stay. The staff were very friendly and helpful. There is a very cute candle shop that you walk by if you're heading to times square. Overall we had a very good stay at the Belvedere Hotel and would stay again in the future!
