The following morning, I went out, and left the do not disturb sign on the door. I had all of my legal papers laid out in my room, and additionally, since I was going to be back at the room shortly, the safe was open w/my computer, camera and travelers checks in it. When I returned to my room, not only was the do not duisturb sign gone, but my key did not work. I called to speak to the hotel manager, and explained the problem. After initially not willing to send someone up top my room w/a new key(they wanted me to go down 17 floors in their VERY slow elevator's), a key was sent up. I got in my room, and saw that the staff had ignore my request sign to not enter, and had cleaned the room. All of my papers that were laid out on the bed, in preperation of my presentation, had been stacked on the room's desk. This was not only going to take me several hours again to lay out, but it violated my privacy. I called the manager again to complain...she said she woul investigate, and get back to me. She never did, and then the head of housekeeping called me, and said he would follow-up. He said they would review the video tapes of the hallway, and see what transpired. Then he left another message, and said the maid had already left for the day, and he offered his assurances he'd contact me in the morning. He also left another housekeeping supervisors' name, and said she was looking into it as well, and would let me know why the room was entered into w/out my authorization. I was a guest there four four nights, and during the entire time, none of the three supervisorial people I spoke w/ever got back to me, or followed through. I travel extensively, and mistakes happen. What compounded a mistake into a serious breach of hotel managements' verbal statements blatantly indicate unprofessionalism at its worst. The hotel's management shows an obvious lack of character and integrity. All parties concerned dropped the ball. No matter how nice a hotel's amenities may be, if a guest can not count on management to do as it says it will do( repeatedly I might add) then what kind of reputation is that for the hotel. I am in NYC every month, and have stayed in many hotels. There is an old proverb...I can't hear what you are saying because what you are is so much louder. The management said they would get back to me, but never did. Disregard for guests....no follow-thru.....poor management.....violation of privacy...all elements of a hotel not worthy of patron's time or money.

<Rating>2	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	

<Author>LorieRobinson
<Content>Expectations Too High I was really looking forward to staying here, based on all the wonderful reviews that The Belvedere got on TripAdvisor. I think my expectations were just a little too high, though, because we experienced a few minor missteps during our stay there that left me somewhat disappointed.First of all, great location. We could walk or take the subway everywhere, which was fabulous. Be sure to head over to all the great little restaurants on 9th; there are dozens and they all look delicious and many are fairly reasonably priced (we loved 44SW, an Italian trattoria on the corner of 44th and 9th).Second of all, the rooms were extremely clean, which, in my opinion, is ultimately the most important thing.Now for the downside. To start, these were singlehandedly the most uncomfortable beds and pillows that I've ever stayed on in a hotel. By the end of our four-day stay, I had all but removed the pillow from the bed because sleeping without was almost more comfortable than sleeping with the pillow.We did not realize that, in order to get our room cleaned, we had to put the card on the doorknob so that it said, Please clean room. In all other hotels I've ever stayed (including in NYC), the default is that your room is cleaned unless you put the card on the doorknob requesting privacy. Here the card had two sides and our room did not get cleaned at all after the first night because we didn't put the card on the knob. We figured it out after that, but it was kind of disappointing to have spent $175/night to come home after a long day of sightseeing to find unmade beds and wet towels.The lock on the safe in our room did not work, which normally would not be a big deal, but we had brought a wireless laptop with us so we could check out restaurant and play reviews, and we were were unable to store it in the safe.There was no remote control for the TV in our room, and the TV didn't work without it. It took them two phone calls and 24 hours to get one for us. We weren't in the room much and we don't watch much TV, but my husband was interested in watching the U.S. Open when he could and I would have liked to have been able to get a weather report.The front-desk clerk was not particularly friendly when we got there, which is fine (it was, after all, 11:30 p.m. when we arrived), but everyone after that seemed friendly. And I was very impressed with The Belvedere's online reservation system -- even my special instructions (late check-in and a request for a room on a higher level) were logged into the system.In all, I guess part of my hesitation about giving The Belvedere a higher review is that I don't know what $175 typically gets you for a hotel in NYC. Maybe what we had was a lot nicer than other places in that price range -- I just don't know. If that's the case, then I am probably being a bit harsh. However, all this is to say that if I went to NYC again, I might very well stay at The Belvedere again, but I would probably look around first and try to get some more recommendations from folks.  
<Date>Sep 13, 2005
<Rating>3	3	3	-1	5	-1	3	-1	

<Author>BostonArt
<Content>Overall Really Satisfied I will give a list of pros and cons and believe me, the cons are picky cons just to throw some in, they are not a big deal at all.PROS:- Great location, just a couple of blocks from Times Square and Rockefeller Center. Lots of bars and places to eat within walking distance.- Doormen are really nice and helpful with getting a cab- Front desk people nice and I was upgraded from a room with 2 doubles to a room with a king sized bed for no extra charge- Room a pretty decent size...on 15th floor and had a good view- Room was generally kept clean and did not have to pay extra to use the in room safe- Price not cheap but not too much...paid $175 a night for weekday and $200 for weekend. You get what you pay for in NYCCONS:- I like to sleep in if out late the night before. There is a place in the hotel for breakfast but it ends at 11am.....this hotel did not have roomservice I was slightly let down by that.- Air conditioning worked fine but it was really noisey at times.- We stayed 4 nights and the last day we were there housekeeping forgot to clean our room...we were out all day and night so when we got in late it kind of was annoying to come back to a room with unmade beds and no clean towels.We would stay there again, but probably will want to stay in a different area of the city next time for a change of scenery.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Stay! Me and 3 friends stayed at the Belvedere for 5 nights. We had 2 double beds, a tv unit, mini fridge and microwave - the rooms were very spacious and very clean. The mini fridge came in handy for water, juice etc. The staff at the Belvedere were extremely helpful and even made quick last minute arrangements for us to get a town car to the airport when we had forgotten to do so in advance (very appreciated!).The elevators were not a problem at all - they are typical elevators.The hotel is in a great, safe location ~ literally a 2 minute walk from Times Square (and walking distance to most areas).Coming in from 90 degree weather it was nice to have the a/c (the unit was a bit noisy, so for light sleepers I would recommend ear plugs - that goes for any hotel with a window a/c unit)I would definitely return to the Belvedere and recommend it to anyone staying in NYC.

<Author>KCtraveler
<Content>A Nice Stay I like many others choose this hotel based on reading so many positive reviews on this website. My opinion of this hotel mirrors most of what everyone else has already stated -- Its a very good option for the price and location. I came into New York City mainly to spend a few days at the US Tennis Open and the hotel is only a few blocks away from the Times Square subway station on route to catching the #7 train to Flushing. I can't comment on eating at the Belvedere as I just walked around a lot and ate at places that struck my fancy. My room was situated on the 17th floor and I had no problems with the elevators. Yes, the elevators are small and can't hold more than 10 people at a time, but they were worked alright and I always had an empty elevator to step into going down from the 17th floor. I will comment that the bathroom is tiny and the lighting is not very bright. The size of the bathroom was not a problem for me but I imagine if you are a portly person that the lack of space might become uncomfortable. All in all I will try to stay at the Belvedere next year when I return to New York City for the US Open. Thats my two cents. Hope its useful to someone.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Belvedere average, a bit disappointed This is my third time to NYC, and I normally stay at the Milford Plaza. Thinking I would rather stay at a nicer place this time, I read the reviews for the Belvedere, and found that it had better reviews overall than the Milford, and that it was just as affordable. Upon my arrival, I was surprised that the lobby was small, and that there was not enough room for arriving guests . . . .there also were not enough elevators to accomodate the amount of guests that were there. Several mornings when leaving the hotel, I had to wait up to half hour to get an elevator that had room for us. The kitchenette was nice, and the room was beautifully decorated, but the room was not any larger than what we had at the Milford. The beds were extremely uncomfortable, like rocks. The bathroom was tiny. The electricity went off several times when we were there, and we had to call someone to come fix it. I do have to say though, that they were prompt in fixing it. I was surprised to find out upon checkout that there were extra charges above what was stated on Travelocity. Being on a fixed budget, this was very disheartening. The staff was very friendly, and the doormen were so kind . . . but I was extremely shocked that no one ever asked us to show our keys, which meant that any stranger could have followed a guest up to their room. I am sure there are much worse hotels to be found, and I definately didn't leave angry . . . but there is much room for improvement.

<Author>ErinMarie79
<Content>Great, clean place My friends and I stayed at the Belvedere from Aug 31st-Sept 5th, 2005. We got a room with 2 double beds, on the 12th floor for $175 US a night. The room was very spacey and clean with a nice view. The fridge was a really nice bonus! The elevators were not the fastest, but we were never in a major rush. The staff was very helpful, and recommended different places to eat. It is very close to Times Square. We tried the Mariott revolving bar/restaurant called 'The View' on Sunday night. We arrived at approx 10:30pm. There was hardly any wait and the view of the city was well worth the drink price ($11+). If you go before 9pm there is no $7 cover charge. We didn't know this little tidbit, but the waitress didn't end up charging us the $7 anyways. I highly recommend everyone try Billy's Bakery in the Lower West Side. It is on 184 9th Ave, between 21st and 22nd. They make melt in your mouth cupcakes, along with other cakes and drinks. Overall, we were very pleased with this hotel and would definitely stay there again!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Hotel Great Location Have just got back from 5 nights at the Belvedere. Having read that some staff in NY can be unhelpful and sometimes rude, there is none of this at this hotel. Staff were always polite and helpful. The room was fine with a king bed, smallish bathroom but ingenius curved shower curtain rail, little kitchenette for a coffee, or keeping drinks cool. We had a room on the front on the 17th floor. It wasn't too noisy - it is NY. Go up the Empire State - you can still hear the noise on the 86th floor!Elevators not a problem for us and we were on the 17th floor. There are two main elevators which hold 8 to 10 people (without luggage) but in the morning when everyone is heading out they can fill up. They still stop at floors requested where the people waiting cannot get in. Their lift 'call' is then cancelled and they must start again. It's the same with any hotel. This aint a 4000 room Vegas hotel with express elevators.Location good for subway and close to Times Sq and Broadway. We walked from the subway at 50th with a single case on wheels direct to the hotel in about 5 minutes.Only problem was checking in when our room wasn't ready (it was 2pm and check in is 4pm) but they said another room was available. Upon getting to the room it was a twin queen 'deluxe' not the 'king' we had booked. When I went to reception I was told that was what was available and when I mentioned I had booked (online) a king the receptionist said that is only a request. However they said we could have a king the next morning which we did without problem. My point here is that the 'king' is more expensive than the 'deluxe' but was told it's only a request!! This is why I gave 4/5 rather than 5/5.

<Content>Belvedere is Best I chose the Belvedere after reading all the comments posted, along with the great rating of 26/324 reviews! It included a fridge, microwave, hairdryer, iron and board, and air conditioning that worked well. <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Belvedere was Excellent We booked online for four nights in mid July, after reading many positive reviews. We were not disappointed with our choice. <Author>Napa_neighbor
<Content>Good place My wife and I spent two nights at the Belvedere in August. We found it to be a great value for the money. It was easy to drive to, valet parking cost $39/day, the staff was friendly and tried to be helpful, and the room was fine. It was larger than we expected and clean but not fancy. The mattress was quite firm. There were 2 TV's, one in the bedroom and one in the small sitting room with a fridge and a microwave and an ugly but otherwise usable sofa. The elevators were often packed but it really wasn't a problem. The bellstaff was helpful and offered some recommendations for restaurants (but their recommendations seemed to be for places they had special relationships with). We would definitely stay here again though we would definitely prefer the W but can't afford it! Also the location about 2 blocks from Times square and the subway was great. The neighborhood seemed very safe also.  
<Date>Aug 23, 2005

<Author>klaatu
<Content>The Belvedere: the perfect place for lovers... My fiance and I stayed at the Belvedere for Ten nights from August, 3rd to August 13th and had the most wonderful stay there.The front desk staff was very professionnal and nice to us for day 1!! The kitchenette was very handy and coupled with the perfect location, we can say thet Blelvedere is the perfect spot for New York explorers (Times Square and the subway line were only two blocks away). Yes, the elevator was slow (and sometimes out of order) which caused many tourist jams but this triggered humourous chats. One piece of advice though: don't try to use the staircase whenever the elevator is out because you'll be out of breath halfway through!!!! It's better to wait in line!!!!Should we go to New York again, Belvedere would be our preferred choice.

<Rating>4	4	4	-1	5	-1	5	-1	

<Author>shirleyD
<Content>Perfect Location My son and I stayed at the Belvedere from August 7 to 11. The location, service, cleanliness, and price are what make this hotel an excellent choice. Our double room wasn't available when we arrived, but they offered us a King room, and immediately sent up a rollaway bed. The room was only just large enough to fit both beds, but that was fine. The bathroom was quite tiny, but that was to make room for a closet that held a safe, iron and ironing board, and plenty of hangars and room to store our empty luggage. It was adequate space for the two of us, but I think if 4 people were sharing the room, it would be a little too crowded. When we arrived, there was no evidence of the problems with slow elevators I had read about from previous reviews - we were up to our room on the top floor immediately. The next day however, was a different story. The two main elevators were out of service and guests were limited to using the one public elevator remaining (or sneak on the employee elevator). Because each one can only hold approx 6 people, it was a long wait to get on one, and just as long to get to the top or bottom, because it would stop on each floor (though there was no room for people to get on). Every member of the staff, from the doormen to the reception staff, to housekeeping and maintenance staff, were all friendly and helpful. I would definately stay here again, but I would ask for a room on the 2nd or 3rd floor, and just use the stairs to save time.  
<Date>Aug 17, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Hotel and perfect location to time square My husband and I stayed at the Belvedere July 7th - 12th, 2005 on the 17th floor. It was our first trip to New York and I researched/priced a lot of hotels. There were a couple of other hotels that caght my interest, that were more expensive....., so I read all the reviews and the reviews for the Belvedere were all thumbs up and the other ones had poor reviews. I actually ended up booking this hotel because of it's reviews, rate and it has a coffee maker and small refrigerator in the room. Most hotels I noticed did not offer a coffee maker much less a refrigerator. There is a resturant in the hotel and a gift shop. My husband I never had time to eat at their resturant...... to busy exploring the streets of New York. At the time I made the reservations, I didn't know exactly where the hotel was located but new it was pretty close to everything in general. I was presently surprised as to how close it was to time square etc..... just 2 blocks. I also have to mention that every New Yorker that my husband I came across were very Nice and Friendly and had no problems giving information. Even if we looked a little lost or puzzled the New Yorkers would come up to us and ask if they could help. We had a great time and can't wait to go back. I would stay at the Belevdere again and would reccomend it to my friends.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Beautiful Belvedere I totally endorse the comments of the reviewer from Kansas. We stayed in the Belvedere from August 1 to 9 and had a great room -410-very quiet at night -except for the essential air con-room cleaned on daily basis, staff unobtrusive but there if you needed them-special mention goes to concierge Leonela Chevalier relation of the great Maurice-when our shuttle bus to JFK was 5 mins late she rang and got one diverted to the Hotel--incidentally the shuttle was 20 dollars per person cheaper in our case 2 people than a yellow cab-I agree that prices in the area were high especially beer and wine but meal deals could be had on 46th street aka Restaurant Row -52 restaurants in one street so competition is fierce. We had a superb steak in Broadway Joes pricey but we used a 20% coupon found in nyc guide books but best value was at the top of 46th the Hourglass Tavern 4 course meals from 14 dollars and he played Doris Day cds too!!!!. All in All a great stay in a very reasonably-for NYC-priced Hotel approx 110 pounds sterling per night.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>The Belvedere is Outstanding!! My wife and I just returned from celebrating our 10th wedding anniversary in New York City (Aug 4th-Aug 7th) and we chose the Belvedere Hotel mainly based upon the reviews we read at TripAdvisor.com. Needless to say, we were not disappointed. The rooms were impeccably clean and very large for a New York hotel room and the rates were so much more reasonable than other hotels in the area!The location is perfect as well. Everything in the Theater District or Times Square was less than a five minute walk away! The section of 48th Street, where the hotel is located, is just inside a residential area which gave it a cozy, safe feeling. The surrounding area was quiet and tree-filled, unlike the constant honking of Times Square and other areas. The staff were extremely polite and we honestly did not find a single thing wrong with our experience. For those of you who are visiting this site trying to decide where to stay in NYC, I can truly say you can not go wrong with this location if your desire is for an enjoyable stay near this part of Manhattan.

<Author>fromdelmar
<Content>Very nice for the price We had a king room and were pleased by the size of the room and in general found the hotel quite good. Negatives: Bathroom was small, but adequate; the hotel has four elevators (not together) when all are working everything is fine, but when one of the two center elevators was being repaired, it took a long time to get to the lobby. Window air conditioning is common in New York. Some of the better hotels have central air, but our window unit kept the room comfortable during 90+ degree weather. Finally, the neighborhood: Convenient to Times Square, but not the nicest neighborhood in the city.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Hotel!!!!! July 20,2005We stayed at the Belvedere Hotel July 7th thru July 13th. I chose this hotel mostly because of the reviews I read on this site. Let me tell you, this is the cleanest, friendliest, most conveniently located hotel I have ever stayed in in NY! The rooms were spacious and very clean, maid service was excellent. We had a problem with the bathtub not draining while we took showers and reported it and it was fixed by the time we got back for the day on that same day. The conceirge is so helpful, they know just about everything, just ask where to eat, how to get somewhere, just anything and they are very knowledgeable and friendly. The bellhops were there, attentively opening doors and smiling. The only problem we had was when we had checked out the last day at noon, and our flight was not until 8:30 pm we had them hold our luggage, they actually store it in a back room which is great, but I asked the bellhop if it would be a problem obtaining a taxi at 5 pm to go to the airport and he said not at all and to not leave past 5:30 pm due to traffic and he would tell the bellhop who would be on duty then to make sure we had a taxi, well that never happened and we got back to the hotel at 4:30 pm and asked them to call a taxi please and they said that would be a problem at this time because taxi's do not like to go to the airport during rush hour so they put their off duty signs on, but he would call for one for us, we waited until 5:20 pm and best he could do was get a private car, whose rate was $35.00 more than a taxi's rate (they have standard rates to JFK and Laguardia Airports). The driver was rude and drove with no patience and experience.Anyway, that is the only negative. The laundry room on the basement level is clean and convenient. I did laundry once and it was a nice plus. The sink in the bathroom is small, but it's not a problem and there is another sink over by the refrigerator and microwave. Really came in handy having refrigerator. We bought water bottles and they kept nice and cold in there and leftovers stayed fresh. Nice TV, took a break with an in room movie inbetween sightseeing, reasonable and they have current movies that are in the movie theaters. My husband and I were traveling with two of our children ages 12 and 13 and they were very comfortable. The elevators were not a problem, we had a great view on the 15th floor.Lot's of places to eat are near by, try the Olympic diner for breakfast right around the corner, quick service, traditional diner type food, good coffee, reasonably priced too. Ray's pizza had good NY pizza also.I would DEFINATELY stay here again, I wish I was still there!!!!!If you have any doubts, just book it, you will be happyJoanneFrom Florida

<Rating>5	5	5	-1	5	-1	5	-1	

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Home from Home! Just returned from my first trip to NY with my best friend, neither of us had been away without our parents so we were quite nervous. Check-in was easy, we requested a low floor, and we got it, (the 6th). Room was plenty big enough, bathroom was fine. It was July so the fridge was vital for cold drinks, fresh fruit etc. Had a large bed each, mine was a little creaky but i got used to it, we stayed 7 nights. Used the elevator at the end of the hall, it was ALWAYS available. We could easliy use the stairs from 6th floor anyway. Rooms were cool even without air con. Did get some street noise during the night but this is unavoidable in NY so get used to it! Housekeeping were good, we never saw them. Clean towels daily. Safe was really easy to use  no extra charge, uses pin code so no key needed. We thought the breakfast at the hotel was a bit pricey for us so we went to the Olympic Diner which was literally around the corner on 8th ave between 48th  49th street it was cheap and did have plenty to choose from, service was lightening fast too. Opposite you will find The Food Emporium which is a handy supermarket, fresh fruit, drinks etc. We also used Ray's Pizza quite a lot, there are several in the area, great pizza by the slice or by the pie you can eat in your room. Saves on the cash if you just want a snack for lunch. TV had some good channels, fellow Brits will recognise MTV, VH1 etc and good for catching up on the news back home, we are from Leeds so we could see American reporters at home investigating the London bombers. Times Square is about a minutes walk away, straight up 48th street, it is so easy to find you way around as the streets are straight and numbered. We walked everywhere midtown  uptown, up as far as 75th street, right across Central Park, 5th ave, 3rd ave, down to Empire State  Macys. The Grayline bus tours leave from 8th ave right near the hotel, for $49 for all loops these tours are great value and the best way to see the WHOLE city. We used them to visit downtown, Ground Zero, Battery park etc. The night tour was fab. I can also recommend NY Waterway which does a 90 minute harbour cruise for $21, down at pier 78 which is a bit of a walk but there is a complimentary bus if you want from Times Square area. As two girls we felt totally safe for our whole trip, even late at night and on foot, NYPD were all over which was reassuring. Because The Belvedere was so near to everything it meant we could go back  forth as we wanted to top up on drinks and cool down. Wouldnt dream of staying anywhere else in NY it had everything we needed and couldnt have been in a better place. Best way to get there from JFK is YELLOW cab, i stress the word yellow as there was a guy at the airport who tried to offer us a cheaper ride, dont be fooled! There is no cheaper taxi than a yellow, we paid $45 flat rate from JFK, plus toll and tip was $55. (compared to the $79 the other guy offered)returning to JFK, the doorman got us a cab within seconds, wasnt flat rate, paid about $5 extra. Had a great trip, a week wasnt long enough, can't wait to go back, loved the hotel and NYC!  
<Date>Jul 18, 2005
<Rating>5	5	5	-1	5	-1	5	-1	

<Author>Beach710
<Content>Belvedere Hotel - Good Location My adult daughter and I stayed at the Belvedere Hotel for four nights in July 2005. For walkers like us, the location was convenient to many places like Central Park, Time Square, theatres and Macys. The hotel was clean but the service was spotty. The front desk was pleasant during check in. We had to call down to get 'extra' towels several days. There were always several bellman/doormen at the door but they didn't bother to open it as we were going in or out. We did not spend much time at the hotel. We did not use the elevator except on arrival and departure with our suitcases since we were only the third floor. It was much quicker to take the stairs. Note: the elevators at the end of the hall have signs on them stating they are staff only elevators. I like having the refrigerator, coffee maker and extra sink. The safe was also a nice feature. I would recommend the Belvedere Hotel if the price was right.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Fantastic Compared to most of the hotels I found In New York , The Belvedere was by far the cheapest and most decent hotel I had seen. This was one of the first times that I had booked a hotel using tripadvisors reviews and I'm very glad that I did. The hotel is in an excellent location two blocks from Times Square in one direction, and Hells Kitchen is one block west, where there are some excellent little restaurants at reasonable prices. The hotel itself was clean, service was good. Overall I would rate it highly however there were a couple of things that got on my nerves (probably because I was staying there 7 nights, longer than most trips to NY, I realise), the lifts were unreliable and at least one was out of service each day and they were very slow. The internet connection was extremely expensive although there is an easynet cafe off Time Square. Overall excellent value for money in NYC!  
<Date>Jul 4, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>not the best Hotel was clean, but very average.Room was ok in size, but bathroom very cramped.Offered extra TV facilities, such as movies and games, but at a price, $11, a bit expensive.Lifts a bit dodgy - creaked and groaned on the 5th floor, thought we got stuck, but just a strange minute or so - front staff didnt appear to be too concerened.Location is close to times square, but also next to a fire station, so sirens can be a bit of a bother.Aircon was new and modern with remote and worked well and we had a nice view of the city skyline.Has a small business centre with internet and computer workstations, but also at a price ($0.25 per minute) - cheaper elsewhere.Also found local hotel restaurant to be on the expensive side.Overall a clean hotel, but very average for the price we paid - have stayed at cheaper and nicer hotels in NYC so probably won't be back

<Rating>3	3	4	-1	4	-1	3	-1	

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Hotel We just got back from a four night stay at the Belvedere, it was great. When I booked the hotel I was unsure from some of the other reviews, but we were really pleased. First of all, the location was excellent, It's on W. 48th street between 8th and 9th ave, on the edge of the theater district. It was perfect because we could walk almost everywhere and weren't far from the subway stop. Restaurant Row is on 9th ave. and so there were great food options, I recommend Joe Allen for pre-theater dinning. You can walk to everyshow and timesquare. The hotel itself was very nice too. The lobby is very nice, and we were always greeted friendly. We were lucky and got a great room, make sure to ask for the highest corner room possible that way it'll be bigger and you'll have a better chance for a good view (and less noise). The room was very comfortable, and a great deal for the price. I would definately recommend the Belvedere Hotel to anyone. It made our vacation really pleasent and fun.  
<Date>Jul 3, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Arrive early or else... My partner  I booked a room confirmed with a credit card at the Belvedere. We were sailing with friends on the QM2 the next day, and the hotel is only several blocks away from the dock. After a late flight and long cab ride from the airport we arrived to find out that they had no rooms available! We were offered a room at their sister hotel 40 blocks north and cash for cab fare to get there. No explanation was ever given as to why the guaranteed room was given away, and we wonder if we'd never shown up if our credit card would still have been billed. Thanks to our generous friends who doubled up in someone else's room and gave us theirs, we did not have to travel farther away. The desk clerk told us he couldn't comp the rooms, but he did reduce the rate on both of them. The hotel itself was okay for NYC, but they need to get their reservation difficulties solved. Because of this hassle I doubt we'd stay there again.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Location, Clean but...... My daughter and I stayed in The Belvedere for six nights. The room was very clean and we appreciated the refridgerator and microwave. It was in a great location for us as we went primarily to see shows and could walk to all. There are a couple of convenient subway stations within a block or two and an easy walk to Times Square and 5th Avenue. There is a great restaurant, Luxia, just two doors down. Unfortunately, the day time front desk staff could have been more friendly (night shift folks were great). We went one entire day without hot water, two days without bath towels, even when I called and asked for some. The In-room movies and bathtub/shower faucet didn't work and it took two maintenance guys (very nice, determined fellows) about 3 hours of putzing around in our room to fix them. On the morning when I only had 3 hours sleep I awoke to find that the maid had neglected to give us coffee (aaaghh!). I began to wonder if it was something personal (I always tip very generously-perhaps that wasn't such a good idea). The window air conditioner was quite noisy but essential in the 95 degree heat. The bellman's recommendation for a restaurant was dreadful. I would stay somewhere else next time even if I have to pay a bit more.  
<Date>Jul 1, 2005

<Author>runfar82
<Content>Would stay here again . . . . I had done a lot of research on hotels and locations. Read all the great reviews on this sight. Most of the negative things seemed insignificant. Thought we might need the refrigertor and microwave, but with all the great places to eat in NYC, there was never a need.The lifts were never a problem. Used the ones at the end of the hall several times. The staff was very courteous. The conceirge did seem to have a little attitude, but she was somewhat helpful with my questions. Not a lot of street noise on the 14th floor. Did hear the fire trucks once and a while, but not a problem.Would recommend Island Burger and Shakes around the corner on 9th Ave, John's pizza a little south off 8th Ave, Olympic Diner on 8th around the corner (waiters very friendly) and the cheap cup of coffee ($.60) around the corner at the tiny grocery on 8th Ave. Ate at Becco (close to hotel) on theatre night. Really enjoyed.We were lucky about getting the breakfast included in our hotel cost. Learned about a code on this sight to mention when we made the reservation. It was very good! Even when we went a little later one day, the food was replenished and fresh. It was one less decision to make each day. I would stay there again.

<Author>Mike1957_7
<Content>Perfect location My wife and I stayed here for two weeks and cannot praise the staff at the Belvedere too highly. Reception, the concierge, the maids, the bellboys were all very helpful. The room on the 17th floor had superb views over 8th avenue as far as the Hudson river on our right. The room was large with a queen bed and a very useful kitchenette with fridge and microwave. Bathroom was small but perfectly adequate if you don't need to stretch out in the tub! Had a faulty hairdrier  a blocked loo one day but both were immediately remedied after reporting to reception. Location was superb - two blocks away from broadway  times square. Great pubs nearby (especially Scruffy Duffys- good value bar snacks) and a smattering of good deli's. Would not hesitate in recomending this hotel for value for money,cleanliness  friendliness.

<Author>DancingQueen76
<Content>Great value and location We just spent five nights at the Belvedere and wanted to thank all the great reviewers here on TripAdvisor. The location is excellent, just steps away from Times Square and tucked in a nice neighborhood with many convieniences. Besides all the restaurants on Broadway, there is a great little park/courtyard one block North of the hotel with tables/chairs, a Starbuck's and a couple restaurants. We found a great bakery and fruit/veggie stand on 9th Ave, and a grocery on 8th. There is also a bistro called Pigalle on 48th/8th that is pretty good for breakfast, and depending on what you get, can be slightly less than the Belvedere breakfast (which is also very good). The room was nice, quiet, with a pleasant view. We liked having the mini fridge. They also have wireless Internet, but you must call the desk each day to get a new login/password. The cost of the room was very reasonable, making it a great value for families like us (two parents, two kids). We found the entire hotel staff to be friendly, helpful, and responsive. We had no problems with elevators or getting extra towels (the towel holder can hold only three sets).

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Comfortable stay at the Belvedere This hotel deserves five stars mainly because of the tremendous value it offers for the money. The decor is plain but the rooms are clean and the kitchenette came in very handy for preparing a simple breakfast. We also used the laundry room, (located in the basement) yet another money saving feature of the hotel... just be sure to bring your own detergent. We were located on the fifth floor, which I had concerns about at first because I know how noisy NY can be, but the neighborhood was relatively quiet and we slept peacefully. There isn't much of a view from the lower floors, but we didn't spend much time in the room.The hotel is located on the edge of Time Square, making it an ideal location for those going to see the shows. Many tour groups frequent the place, so it can be a madhouse. Nevertheless, the staff handled the full house with efficiency and expertise. The staff was polite and professional. We were allowed to check in as soon as we arrived (at noontime) and they also held our bags until we were ready to go to the airport for our departure. I forgot my house and car keys and left them in the room when we checked out. When I called the next day to see if they had been found, the concierge took immediate action to mail them to my home.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Place We just got back from 5 nights at the Belvedere. It was perfect. When you book online in a city that's 5000 miles away you always are taking a chance and since I had nothing to go on but the reviews at Tripadvisor I was a bit nervous. Add to this that it was our 20th anniversary and you can't believe the relief I felt when we saw this place. The staff were top notch; the room was fantastic; no too large but clean and nicely appointed. The mattress was good and the location of this hotel was perfect. Times Square is 2 blocks, the Subway is 2 blocks. We walked to the theatres (Movin' Out - (6 out of 10) and Rent (9 out of 10) on two of the nights because they were less than 10 minutes away. Safe neighbourhood. Yes there is a fire hall a block away and we heard them occasionally in the night but other than that the rooms were very quiet. When we go back I wouldn't consider staying anywhere else. The Brazilzian resteraunt on the back side of the hotel (facing 49th) was very good - However the best meal we had was at a place called One if by Sea two if by land on Barrow street in Greenwhich Village. Stunning food and service - a bit pricey but it's New York!Can't wait to go back and stay at the Belvedere

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Large rooms, but a few problems The rooms here were bigger than any room I can imagine in NYC. The room was relatively clean - just a few bits of torn wallpaper and the window air conditioner made it seem not as nice as I originally had hoped. However, there were a few issues. They also charged us an extra $30 a night for the extra 2 people...although I should have read the fine print in booking it on Travelocity, it was still a surprise. The location was okay, but it was still a few blocks further from the theatres than I was hoping for.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Stay here/save your money for dining and drinking! I researched hotels for 6 mos. prior to visiting NYC in early June of 2005. This was the first time my husband and I stayed in a hotel in NYC, so I wanted it to be nice but not too pricey. I kept checking the reviews here and rarely heard ANY complaints about this hotel. I finally made our reservation here and kept checking reviews and was always so excited to hear how everyone was satisfied. I couldn't wait to visit. Tip: Don't take an airlink shuttle or a supershuttle from LGA airport to this hotel. Nightmare experience on the way in. On the way out, took a cab and it was so easy, fast and THE SAME PRICE for two of us!!! I wish someone would have told us this.Check in was perfect, room was spacious, VERY clean, and quiet. We were on the 12th floor facing the back (49th st.). Staff was always helpful and friendly. Loved having the in-room safe and the kitchenette and ironing board/iron. I used my hair dryer from home and blew a fuse...called the desk and 5 min. later the power was back on.Elevators were small and a bit slow but not bad enough to bum you out too much. We just used the service elevators at the end of the halls a few times (especially at night). Nobody cared and you didn't have to wait at all. Didn't eat at the hotel restaurant, but ate at 2 very close and very good restaurants on 9th street: The Delta Grill (Cajun/Rest./Bar) and Amarone (Italian) - both excellent and less than a block away (out the hotel door, turn right to 9th st., cross the street and they are both on the left.Like everyone says, great location, friendly staff, great rooms, great price - why would you go anywhere else?

<Author>shariberry99
<Content>Non Smoking at the Belvedere We stayed for 5 nights at the Belvedere in early June. Great price for a room in NYC. The whole hotel is a non smoking hotel which is great. The elevators were a little slow and small, but that did not deter from the our group liking this hotel. The staff was very friendly, even made jokes with us when we had them store our bags after checkout, but before we wanted to leave the city. The towels could be a little newer. One day they smelled a little bit burnt. (maybe they need a new dryer). The rooms were large. We had a room with two full beds and enough space between. There was a small fridge with microwave and coffee maker. The window would open about 4 inches if you like fresh air. The noise from the street came through, but I don't like the feel of A/C. This hotel is two blocks from Restaurant Row and within walking distance to many on Broadway theaters, so you won't be spending a lot on cab fair. We took the Gray Line hop on, hop off bus tour. Well worth the $49. for 48 hours. Tour guides really know a lot about NY. Bring an extra suitcase, there is so much shopping it is addicting. (and we come from San Diego) So, pick Mr. Belvedere hotel when traveling to NYC.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great value for the money It was very difficult finding a hotel in New York City for under $200.00 a night. After extensive research, I was able to locate the Belvedere Hotel, in the heart of the theatre district. I was traveling alone on business, and concerned about safety. The Belvedere was a real bargain; spacious rooms (with two double beds), a full closet, kitchenette, full dressers, desk, chair, etc. The location was ideal and I easily walked to business appointments, cafes and restaurants. Major subways and bus lines were on just about every corner. And, some theatres were on the same block as the hotel. The staff was welcoming and friendly and assisted in shipping materials back home, identifying car services, arranged for reservations, and generally did an excellent job. If you are on a budget, this is the place to stay in the theatre district.

<Author>demonloop
<Content>Lived up to its reviews on this site. Just got back from NYC. We stayed in the Belvedere for 9 nights. I'm in the UK and had based ALL my faith in the Belvedere after reading reviews on this site alone. We weren't disappointed. There was two of us travelling, myself and my girlfriend. After flying into JFK we found the AirTrain very easily which took us to Howard Beach subway station for $5. From there we caught the blue line to 50th St station for $2. Beats paying $60+ for a taxi! We got to the hotel a little early; check-in is 3pm, we were there at 2pm. We had requested a room with queen bed and a corner room at time of booking, so expected to wait about for a while but the very friendly staff had a room waiting. Check-in was simple and easy to understand, everything was explained clearly and very friendly.The room was great, more than we expected. It was impeccably clean, the only place I could find dust was on a small spot on top of the TV unit; I had to look hard!!The bathroom was immaculate and plenty big with shower and bath combo.The fridge worked great, never tried the microwave. There were plenty of towels, which were changed every day. The AC worked great too. The TV was far bigger than hotel TVs in the UK.I had read the comments about the lifts being small/slow. In truth they were a little small, sometimes when one stopped for you it was full and you had to wait on another, but in my opinion you need to be very picky to let this bother you. Our room was cleaned every day whilst we were out as well.The hotel restaurant was a little over-priced in comparison to the local ones, even for breakfast the diners down the street were cheaper and better. We tried the hotel breakfast once and didn't go back, it wasn't bad but the diners were better.The location was excellent, a short walk to 42nd St and the theater district and there were subways ay 50th St and then the big 42nd St one a short walk away.At night there wasn't much noise, its in a quiet little corner just off the main noisy area. The location was perfect. I hope to return to NYC soon and I won't be even choosing a hotel I will be staying at the Belvedere.

Now location: we were two blocks from Times Square, three blocks from Broadway, and there were a TON of great restaurants all around us. This hotel seemed too good to be true given the price was so low but it really is great. Also, the award-winning brazillian restaurant downstairs is UNBELIEVABLE. While eating dinner we saw all kinds of cabs pull up out front meaning that even people not staying at the hotel still come to eat dinner at this place.

<Author>jdblakesle
<Content>Great hotel! Great location! We spent four nights at The Belvedere Hotel, 5/24 - 5/28/2005. We had two rooms, one with a king bed, one with two doubles. Both rooms weredecorated nicely, both had a microwave, coffee-maker, and a frig.The bathrooms were smallish, but very modern and had recently been renovated, with new tile and fixtures. The towels were plush and new.Each room had a large TV and a desk  chair with high-speed internet access. There is a business center with internet access, too.We did not eat in the cafe, as we loved the Pigalle cafe just a block up W 48th Street, open 24/7. We booked our rooms via Quikbook and paid $155 each per night. For this price, this is nicest hotel we've used in NYC,and the location can't be beat. For individuals booking this hotel, please note that lots of tour companies use this hotel for their groups. The complaints about the slow elevators were exaggerated. One of our rooms was on the 17th floor and we never waited longer than a few minutes for one to arrive, and this hotel was booked solid during our entire stay. The staff is great and friendly, eager to help in any way they can.Don't be afraid to use this hotel for a wonderful stay in a great city!!

<Author>devan
<Content>Great find! I stayed at the Belvedere May 18 - 23. I booked this hotel based on reviews here and I am SO glad I did! It's just as good as everyone says. The value is incomparable. My room had two double beds, a chest, an armoire and desk and there was STILL plenty of room to move around! Not easy to find in New York.Room and bathroom were super-clean and the kitchenette was very handy. I arrived a few hours before check-in but they let me go up to my room right away. I saw others who arrived before their rooms were ready having no problem checking their bags.I loved the location. Very short walk to the major subway lines. Walking distance to the theaters but away from the bustle of Times Square. Very convenient to Restaurant Row (though I stuck mainly with the restaurants along 9th Avenue, which aren't quite as pricey and many are very good). Along with a deli on the corner, you can stock up on gourmet goodies at the Amish Market, a short walk away on 9th Avenue. There's also a Food Emporium and Rite-Aid close by.Yes, the elevators can be a problem depending the time of day, but that's a minor thing compared to what you get for the price you pay. I will definitely be back!  
<Date>May 27, 2005
<Rating>4	5	4	-1	5	-1	4	-1	

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Rooms as Good as the Waldorf My wife and I stayed at the Belvedere for 4 days just after Thanksgiving 2004. We found all the good things about this hotel to be true, and were extremely pleased with our choice. Here is our experience:Location: Perfectly located just on the fringe of all the action. We walked almost everywhere we wanted to go, and it was especially convenient to the theater district. We went to all the major sights and attractions and never felt like it was too far to walk. The two times we did need a taxi to travel long distances, the wait time outside the hotel was just a couple minutes. It makes a big difference to the volume level of the street to be in this relatively quiet block. In the 4 days we were there, we never heard sirens from the nearby fire station. Hotel Interior and Room: We found everything to be consistently very clean and fresh. The hallways are well lit, very clean and freshly painted. Based on recommendations on this site, we did use the elevators at the end of the hall, and they were generally much quicker than waiting for the main elevator. We were two doors from the main elevator, and we were never bothered by noise, etc. The room size was exactly what you鈥檇 expect for NYC, and it never felt cramped. We used the microwave and fridge everyday as we took advantage of the corner market to get our juice, breakfast, soft drinks and bottled water. The bathroom was as clean as any hotel I鈥檝e been in. After checking out of the Belvedere, I moved to the famous Waldorf=Astoria for several nights on business. Other than a larger closet and complementary robe, I can honestly say the Waldorf guest rooms are no better than the Belvedere. I even thought the bathroom was cleaner at the Belvedere than the Waldorf. The Belvedere is a tremendous value considering the Waldorf charges two to three times more. I鈥檇 also give the edge to the Belvedere since the street sounds you hear in your room are so much less than the honking and commotion around the Waldorf all day long. For anyone looking for a smart value in NYC, the Belvedere is it, hands down.  
<Date>May 23, 2005

<Author>t13nif
<Content>Absolutely perfect I stayed at the Belvedere with my elderly mother May 7-12. We arrived late Saturday night and were given a room on the back side of the hotel, on the third floor. The check-in staff were extremely polite, friendly and professional (much to my surprise, having been prepared for some New York abruptness). The room was non-smoking and smelled that way-- unlike some non-smoking rooms which smell like ashtrays. Everything was spotlessly clean. The 2 double beds were very comfortable and there was an extra blanket and pillow in the large closet. The kitchenette was very handy for coffee making in the morning and keeping bottled water cool for siteseeing. We had the full brunch in the cafe on Sunday morning and even though we arrived 20 minutes before it ended, the food was fresh and excellent. The room was extremely quiet at night--i have quite a bit more street noise in my apartment in the suburbs of Vancouver. The room temp was fine, not too hot or cold and i was also pleased to find full cable television. We never had one problem with the elevators and the staff were always very helpfull and friendly. I am sooo glad i found this website and was able to book this hotel. I will not hesitate to stay here again and will recommend it to anyone and everyone. My only fear is that they will realize how great they are and raise the prices :).

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great location, friendly staff, great room but got to fix those lifts! This hotel really is as good as others say it is. The room was clean and comfortable. The staff are friendly. Times Square is but a few minutes walk away, as are shops, bars, restaurants and the bus tour stops. And there's a superb little deli on the corner. I would have given five out of five except for the barely visible crack in the basin in the kitchen and the fact that after a day or two one of the lifts broke down, which caused a bit of delay for guests trying to check out. I spoke to a fellow guest who told me he'd been coming to The Belvedere for many years and the lifts were always breaking down. Oh, and you have to pay to play the Nintendo on your TV set. (But then who has time to play Nintendo when New York is outside? Not me!) Overall, I would definitely recommend this hotel, especially to first time visitors.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Wrong room.....again I can recommend this hotel for everything-location, comfort, facilities etc., only thing that marred our stay was for the second time in NY, when checking in was given the wrong room. When booking 3 months earlier I specifically requested a double double room,ie. 2 beds (confirmed), only to be told on arrival that they did not have one available and allocated a one bed suite for the first night. We had a rollaway bed sent up which filled the sitting area and was far from comfortable. The following day we had to vacate this room and take our luggage down to the foyer for storage until after 4pm that day when our requested room would be ready. This meant we had no room to return during the day and it was after waiting in Reception from 4pm-4.45pm that we finally were able to unpack our cases. For a short stay in NY we could have spent our time a lot better. On examining the bill we found that we had actually been charged extra for the suite! I advise anyone with particular requirements to double check before travelling. As stated earlier this is the 2nd time this has happened to us (different hotel 1st time). I wonder if it is only overseas visitors who are treated this way. Would like to point out that no apologies were made.

<Rating>4	3	4	-1	4	-1	2	-1	

<Author>MicheleNY
<Content>A perfect retreat after a day/night in New York City My boyfriend and I were planning a night out in the city, so after reading the reviews online, I reserved a night for us at The Belvedere. We live an hour train ride away, but since it was going to be a long night, I thought as long as I found a good place, we would spend the night. And I did! The price was right and the location couldn't have been better. As soon as we arrived, the courteous staff checked us in with no delay. I had asked for a room higher up with a view, so when we finally reached the 16th floor, I was thinking maybe I should have asked for a lower room. But I'm happy I didn't...the room was clean and spacious with a lovely view. The air conditioning made the room comfortable and blocked out any noise from the streets below.  My only complaints are that there is only one ice machine (on the 2nd floor) and as soon as I stepped off the elevator, it looked like a run-down apartment complex. I realized the higher up I went, it seemed cleaner and quieter. So if you don't mind waiting for the elevator and walking a bit for ice, ask for a room above the 10th. And they only give you three pillows for a queen/king, so unless you feel like having a tug-a-war in the middle of the night, call down for extras! The Belvedere is right off of Broadway, so it took us less than five minutes to get to our comedy show at Carolines. And the hotel is just around the block from Restaurant Row (47th), where anything and everything is being served, you just have to make up your mind. The hotel is also right next to a mexican restaurant, and being that it was cinco de mayo, we enjoyed a few margaritas before returning to our comfortable room. After a long night of fun, it was a perfect retreat. And check out time is 12:00, so we were able to sleep in a little longer before making a train home.  Being that we live close to New York City, it was one of the few times I have stayed over. But the next time I do, I will be sure to stay at The Belvedere.  
<Date>May 18, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Excellent Midtown Hotel My wife, child and I stayed at the Belevedere for 6 nights on our first trip to the Big Apple. It was a wonderful place to go after wearing ourselves out sightseeing. Near subways (we took the A train from JFK and back), Broadway theaters, Times Square, and Central Park. <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>The Boiled Egg Controversy Checking in and out were fine and the reservation I made through their website was confirmed. The rooms are a bit shabby and old, but it's New York and $160 - $180 per night, which is what I paid, wasn't bad for what I got. (Of course the lobby was the fanciest part of the hotel).The biggest problem I had with the place was their breakfast cafe and the way they completely ripped me off. A misunderstanding occured between me and the hostess (who was rude and welcomed people to the cafe in a glaring sort of way) about two boiled eggs. Having ordered the continental breakfast, I wrongly thought that boiled eggs were included with the continenal breakfast since they were next to the juice and coffee bar. The hostess simply came over and said that those eggs were not included in the continental breakfast. I replied by saying: Oh, I didn't know. I apologize. Thinking that it would be pointless to even ask if she wanted me to put them back (major health code violations), I didn't say anything beyond that. She said nothing in response. Not even a I'll have to charge you for a full breakfast or anything like that. Being from a more laid-back city, I took that to mean she would just take my apology as a simple mistake (as I didn't intentionally try to take things that weren't included in the smaller breakfast) and not charge me for a full breakfast. Much to my surprise and disgust, she charged me five extra dollars for those two of the most dry and drab boiled eggs I'd ever eaten! I refused to sign for the meal with that extra charge and asked to see her manager. Handily, he was not there at the time. Being in a rush to get to a conference uptown, I had to leave and figured I would deal with the issue at checkout time. When that time came, I explained the misunderstanding to the front desk rep and she said she could make an adjustment on my bill. However, she then noticed that the property manager had actually made a note in there saying not to adjust my meal charge! Just absolute frustration at something so silly.In short, the behavior I encountered at this hotel really turned me off to New York as it kind of reinforced the big city stereo types of being hustlers and super-sticklers. If I ever venture to New York again, I will be certain to NOT stay at the Belevedere or any of its affiliated hotels. They may have gotten an extra 5 bucks out of me this time but they will never get another $1,000 from me or anyone I know who is going to New York. Thanks for reading this review.  
<Date>May 18, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Hotel Belvedere felt like a 5 star hotel!! I have traveled to New York many times for business in the past 10 years and usually stayed at the Crowne Plaza. This was a vacation trip and my first time staying at the Belvedere Hotel. My Mother and I went for 3 nights and I can't think of one complaint! This was one of the best hotel experiences I have had. I was expecting at least the elevators to be slow from previous reviews I read, but I never experienced any problems with them. As for the noise, well this is New York you are not staying in the country. The street noise was never excessive and never kept us up. You can always run the fan or air conditioner in your room. The staff was superb! and the rooms were magnificent! Everything was spotless!!! It is a nice size room and bath. You can't ask for a better location or room for the price. You are close to everything and it is a very safe street. I will definitely recommend this hotel to anyone going to New York and when I go back this is where I will be staying. They offer a breakfast brunch and a continental breakfast that is reasonably priced. There is also a very clean deli that is open 24 hours, down the street (only 4 buildings away) so if you want anything you can get it.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Highly Recommended I stayed at the Belvedere from 7th to 12th May with my elderly Mother. They are quite small and slow at busy times but then they would be in any hotel. The rooms are a little shabby but were clean and comfortable. Apparently some rooms have been refurbished so may be worth asking about them.The breakfast in the hotel cafe was excellent value offering two options, cold buffet or hot buffet. Location was excellent, very near 'restaraunt row' and theatreland. Easy walking to Times Square and within a short taxi ride to many 'must see' locations.I would have no hesitation in recommending this hotel, very good value for money.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Thank You Tripadvisor When beginning our search for a Manhattan hotel for our first trip to New York we read of all the horror stories of people having to keep their socks on whenever in their room because of the dirty conditions. We searched the tripadvisor reviews and found that the Belvedere was the highest rated hotel that was within our budget. We booked but were still nervous. Then spoke with a co-worker who had previously stayed at the Belvedere and they raved about it. When we got there we were still pleasantly surprised. The room was fantastically clean and bigger than we expected. It wasn't huge but was plenty big with a desk and seating area. The room was in great condition with nice tile and carpet. Bathroom was modern and there was plenty of hot water. Our room was next to the elevator and I was apprehensive about noises during the night. No problem. We did hear occasional sirens from outside during the night but that must be expected and we did not hear any traffic noise. No noises from within the hotel bothered us at all.The location is fantastic. Within walking distance to all of the theaters, Time Square, subways, Empire State Building, St. Patricks Cathedral, and most importantly to my wife - Tiffany's.Great accomodations and value. We're already planning our next trip to the Big Apple and will definitely be staying at the Belvedere.

<Author>tourists
<Content>A good choice! We have just returned from a 5 night stay at the Belvedere which was excellent! We booked because of the reviews on TripAdvisor and you guys didnt let us down.The rooms are fantastic (try and get one on the top - 17th - floor) they're very clean and in good repair. The beds are massive and really comfy, the bathrooms are spacious and fully equipped. The staff are efficient and pleasant, plus, there's always a doorman on duty so you feel very safe at all times.The area is a little more 'Times Square' than we'd have hoped for i.e. not as residential or moneyed as Midtown East, however, you get a lot for your money.For a superb and inexpensive massive, tasty American breakfast try the Edison Cafe at the Edison Hotel on West 47th, Broadway  8th (2 minute walk).Forget Restaurant Row for dinner, but do pop in to 'Don't tell Mama' (West 46th St) to hear currently-out-of-work Broadway stars sing a tune for free! What a scream - its a bit camp but hey!You should also try and squeeze in Sunday brunch at Oscars cafe at the Waldorf Astoria (Park Ave), its not expensive and the eggs benedict is delicious.Try and do the Empire State at dusk-into-night - you get several excellent and different views of the city in one go. Also try and get tickets online to see a baseball game, at either the Mets or the Yankees' stadium. Whatever you do, dont go to Smith  Wollensky's famous steak house (3rd Ave). The steaks are charred and acrid and you pay $40 for the priviledge. A side order will set you back a further $10 per head.The shopping isnt as great as we'd hoped - but you can pick up some great bargains at TJ Maxx on Ave of the Americas and Macy's if there's a sale on.The best tip we have is - take a yellow cab, everywhere - its a few bucks and you save your feet and a lot of time!

<Author>GilaIsrael
<Content>great location, unpleasant staff, elevator problem This was my second stay at the hotel and the 2 main problems were not solved. The elevators are crowded most of the time, with one of the 2 out of order for about half of the time. Since it is a 17 storey hotel, it is a very serious problem. I had to drag my two suitcases down the stairs from the 5th floor, because even the bell boy could not make it on time (I am a 60+ lady!).The frontdesk staff were sometimes unfriendly (in contrast, the bell boys were very helpful). We asked to store part of our luggage as we were going to Washington for several days and returning to the same hotel. The manager would not hear of it and did not suggest any solution to our problem. (We found out that we could store it at Penn Station, but he did not tell us about it).Part of the rooms were renovated but in the others the carpets need urgent cleaning. The bathrooms are fine. The kitchenette (one of the reasons I came back to this hotel) has a microwave, coffee-maker and small fridge and sink. Very convenient. The location is great (the other reason for my staying at this hotel).If they solve the elevator problem and hire nicer people, I may return.

The reception staff were wonderful, allowing us to stay in the room and watch a movie until we had to leave for the airport (late check-out). <Author>nybor666
<Content>Quite OK but not special We had two rooms here for a week in April 05. It's clean, it's mostly well run (we had a few gripes, nothing very serious, such as long waits for the elevators; cramped and somewhat old-fashioned bathrooms; a failure to fix a fault we reported). It's an acceptable and pleasant hotel. But it really isn't as special as most reviewers here seem to think. We've found better elsewhere in mid-town in the past. One tip: for a very good-value breakfast with fine service, head round the corner to the Olympic Diner at 807 8th Ave.

<Author>LFL1195
<Content>Value for Money We just returned from a 5 night stay at the Belvedere. Over-all, we consider this an excellent hotel for the money. Like others have said, our few beefs were:1. slow and crowded elevators2. very warm temperatures in the room3. beds a bit hardHowever, one of the elvators was out of order for the first two days of our stay and things improved considerably once it was fixed.There was an air conditioner in the window, and even though it was cool outside, we felt we needed to turn it on regardless of the time of year.I really liked having the kitchenette and especially liked that it was out of the way and it didn't feel like it was right in your bedroom.The location was perfect. We walked everywhere. Had breakfast every day at the Olympic restaurant around the corner and picked up our room snacks and drinking water at the Food Emporium across the street (from the restaurant not the hotel). We would definately stay here again!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>loved it! great hotel for the price, i really reco this hotel! It's not the Ritz, but guess what, for a really cheap price you get: a clean, quiet room with comfortable beds; walking distance of Times Square, Theatre District, Rockefeller Center, Museum of Modern Art, St. Patrick's Cathedral, etc.; a nice restaurant in the hotel that serves great breakfasts (didn't stick around for lunch or dinner, so can't give you any info about that); polite staff; really helpful bellboys (getting cabs for us, etc....please just remember to tip the bellboys when they help you out, though--I saw a lot of tourists not doing this, and they should!!!).I stayed here with 5 family members during a week in March 2005. This seems like mostly a tourist hotel and there were a lot of school groups, it seemed. Despite the number of tourists, it was quiet in the hallways and we were able to get good nights sleep. The hotel is in a nice, safe area and I would definitely return.This is not a high price hotel, but it is more than worth the price. They could probably charge more for this hotel and get away with it!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Excellent accommodation in a central location I have just returned from a three night stay at the Belvedere with my niece. This is a great hotel which is sited very close to Times Square - an excellent location. We arrived at 11.15 am and only waited 20 mins before we were allocated a room - pretty efficient seeing that check in time is 3.00 pm. The staff are very pleasant and helpful. The bedroom was located on the 5th floor and was spacious and in excellent decorative order with a little kitchenette. Everywhere was super clean and was cleaned thoroughly every day. They serve a buffet breakfast - which I can recommend as you can fill up for the day and then eat again in the evening. There are lots of deli's and restaurants nearby. It is worth buying a ticket on the sight-seeing bus for $49 for 48 hrs - make sure you do the night tour - fantastic. Before going to New York I did a lot of research of hotels on Trip Advisor and taking comments and the rating number decided on the Belvedere and I am sure glad I did. You can pay a lot more money for a hotel stay but you will not get better, friendlier service in a superb tourist hotel. I am going to Florence in June and have chosen my hotel, again from Trip Advisor, so I am hoping I will be pleasantly surprised again.

<Author>crisssbit
<Content>Loved the Belvedere We spent a week in March at this hotel. We chose it after reading the reviews on this website.It was fantastic! Just 3 min. from Times Square, and two blocks from the nearest Subway station (50th street). Yes, there is a FDNY station house at the corner with the 8 Ave, but it wasn't a bother, even if our room was at the third floor.There are a lot of restaurants nearby. Anyway, The Food Emporium on the 8th Ave was perfect for breakfast!The room was big, two double beds, a small clean bathroom with tub/shower and a kitchenette. Beds were very comfortable. In the room there were a desk with lamp, two phones, an alarm clock, TV, Nintendo, safety box, and a hairdryer in the bathroom.The staff was helpful and very nice. After checking-out, we left the luggage at the hotel, so we could buy the last souverinrs at Times Square.There is also a souvenir shop at the Lobby level: you can find stamps for your postcards there.Overall we had a great time here and no problems at all!!For our next trip to New York City, we will choose the Belvedere again.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Make the Belvedere your first choice!!! Believe the hype! For an exceptional price, we got a clean spacious room with two comfortable double beds. The kitchenette with microwave and refrigerator was especially handy for storing and reheating leftovers, and snacks. (During my intial research, I found that most NYC hotels were tiny and didn't have as much as a mini-bar.) Everything you need is within two blocks of the hotel - Times Square, subways, buses, post office, dozens of restaurants, and convenience stores. The staff were attentive, pleasant, and polite. The Cafe serves a delicious breakfast in lovely booths with art-deco styled scalloped seating. It's true that the main elevators are slow - but there are also elevators at the end of the hall that aren't slow at all. The room can get a little warm but it cools quickly by opening the window or turning on the A/C. Consult the website for reservations and specials - for under $160 we were able to get the room AND free buffet breakfast at the Cafe for the entire length of our stay. If you're on a budget and would rather spend money on sightseeing and shopping, the Belvedere is the absolute best value. You don't have to sacrifice quality to save money...  
<Date>Apr 2, 2005
<Rating>5	5	5	-1	4	-1	5	-1	

<Author>JaneinCordoba
<Content>Brilliant Belvedere We booked through expedia in September after reading the reviews on this site. We stayed in the Belvedere from 21st to 27th March and booked a room for three. We arrived at around 2pm from the Aer Lingus morning Dublin flight and our room was ready, although check in isn鈥檛 officially until 4pm. The room was no smoking, very clean and spacious, with two double beds. There was a safe in the wardrobe which was easy to use. TV reception for all channels was fine-we mainly watched the weather channel for up to date information before we planned our day! The bathroom had a powershower-hot water all day. If you want them to, the room will be cleaned and the towels changed every day. Fridge, microwave and coffee maker were very handy-we bought bottled water and beer from the one of the shops around the corner.We were on the 4th floor (406) and it was very quiet-we heard no noise from neighbouring rooms or anywhere else on the corridor and there was little noise from the street outside. Some other reviews on this site have commented on the elevators being slow; we took the stairs every day so the only day we noticed this was when we took our luggage down on the last day, so I鈥檇 allow an extra 10 minutes for this if you鈥檙e leaving in the morning.The room was always warm but as it was about 5 degrees C we didn鈥檛 mind this. The receptionists were very helpful and we booked the taxi to the airport through them. We also held our luggage over for a couple of hours on the last morning. The hotel is very central to everything. We didn鈥檛 eat in the hotel so I can鈥檛 comment on this.This was my second visit to New York and I鈥檇 previously stayed in the Milford Plaza-the Belvedere is so much better and I would highly recommend it. Clean, comfortable and quiet-what more do you want?In the vicinity鈥?. For a very cheap light breakfast I鈥檇 recommend The Food Emporium (turn left out of the hotel then left again at the top of the road and it鈥檚 across the street). You can get croissants, bagels etc and sit in and eat them. For a lazy dinner, try The Sombrero two doors down from the hotel, a very reasonable Mexican restaurant, and then go for drinks afterwards in The Social (left at the bottom of the street).

<Rating>5	4	5	-1	4	-1	4	-1	

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Loved the Belvedere (not the reception staff, though!) I recently stayed at the Belvedere with my mother (I was encouraged by the reviews here on the Trip Advisor website) and we were not disappointed. I saw from some reviews that it's advisable to stay on a floor as high up as possible so the noise from the street (especially the fire trucks from the fire station on 8th Avenue) don't disturb you so much. I asked to stay in a room on a floor higher than the 12th floor and got a lovely comfortable room on the 14th floor (could barely hear the fire trucks from up there, but the street was fairly quiet anyway). The room was a generous size compared to most you get in Manhattan and the fantastic bonus was the kitchenette complete with fridge, coffee maker and microwave oven. My mother is Type 2 Diabetic and so it was very handy to have this facility on tap as we could make sure we were stocked up on snacks for her to keep her blood sugar levels stable. We had two very comfortable double beds, clock radio alarm, television featuring pay-per-view movies and music and a lovely bathroom. The staff - from the maids to the concierge to the doorman couldn't be more helpful and polite, but here's the one weak link in the chain - the reception/check-in staff. They had a brusque, barely civil attitude which somewhat let down an otherwise perfect stay. It wasn't that I encountered one bad apple, as two or three of the reception/check-in staff had an attitude problem and it seemed like they were having to tolerate you instead of wanting to be helpful and make you feel welcome, which is the most important aspect of a hotel receptionist/check-in person. There was also a small discrepancy in the final bill which was rectified after I queried it, but again, with an attitude, and the receptionist charged my credit card with the amount quoted on the bill before I agreed to it, then reimbursed the incorrect amount once they realised a mistake had been made on their part. Anyway, that's the only one flaw in the whole stay. I would still go back to stay there anytime and would recommend anyone else to do so too. The location is extremely central and very accessible. Superb value for money.  
<Date>Mar 30, 2005

<Author>Pdxgirl51
<Content>Loved The Belvedere My son and I spent 5 days (3/5 through 3/10) at the Belvedere Hotel and loved it. Our room the first night was noisy but the hotel staff was very accomodating in getting our room changed to a higher floor and that made the remainder of our stay quite enjoyable. We also had a problem with the TV and that was also remedied quickly. The hotel is in a great location, just two blocks from Times Square and not far from subway and bus, and cabs are always near the door. The rooms are clean and a good size. The bathroom is small but adequate with tub, shower and plenty of towels. The bell staff and concierge were very helpful with directions and recommendations. The restaurant on 49th Street, Plataforma was wonderful. The hotel is two blocks from Restaurant Row and I would also recommend Becco Restaurant. I would definitely stay at the Belvedere again.
